question:
Contextual materials: African swine fever (ASF) is a serious disease of domestic pigs caused by a DNA arbovirus (African swine fever virus [ASFV]) belonging to the family Asfaviridae (1). Its highly contagious nature and ability to spread over long distances make it 1 of the most feared diseases of pigs; it causes devastating effects on pig production as manifested in the Caucasus since its introduction from southeastern Africa during 2007 (2). Considerable spread of ASF has been reported in western Africa during the past 20 years, and, except for in Côte d'Ivoire, the disease remains endemic (3). Because discernible ASFV serotypes are lacking, the field strains are grouped genetically by using sequencing of the C-terminus of the p72 protein, which discriminates 22 genotypes (4,5). Genotype I is historically associated with outbreaks in western Africa, whereas viruses from southern and eastern Africa have higher heterogeneity, with all 22 known genotypes having been recorded within the region (5-7).
question: Because clear ASFV serotypes are not distinguishable, molecular epidemiology classifies field isolates into 22 genotypes by sequencing a particular genomic region. Which option correctly identifies the locus used (and the reasoning behind using it) for this genotyping method?
A: Sequencing the C-terminus of the p54 protein gene, because this region evolves fastest and resolves all endemic strains into 22 serotypes
B: Sequencing the N-terminus of the p72 protein gene, because it encodes the dominant neutralizing epitope that defines serotypes
C: Sequencing the LCR/noncoding region, because ASFV is a DNA arbovirus whose serotypes are defined by transcription-factor binding site variation
D: Sequencing the C-terminus of the p72 protein gene, because antigenically defined serotypes are lacking and this region differentiates 22 genotypes

question:
Contextual materials: Human-origin influenza A(H1N1) pandemic 2009 (pdm09) viruses are regularly isolated from swine in North America and Europe (1, 2). The global seasonal spread of A(H1N1)pdm09 influenza viruses in humans and their re-introduction into swine resulted in the generation of circulating swine-associated genetic clades (3, 4). The reintroduction of human viruses into swine was estimated to have occurred at least 133 times, globally, leading to the circulation and reassortment of these viruses with other circulating swine influenza A viruses (1,5). Reassortment of human A(H1N1)pdm09 viruses with North American swine influenza viruses containing the triple reassortant internal gene (TRIG) cassette was also identified resulting in numerous genome constellations found in pigs since the 2009 pandemic (6, 7). This onward reassortment of swine-origin A(H1N1)pdm09 influenza viruses has greatly increased their genetic variability and generated novel genotypes of unknown phenotypic and epidemiologic consequences.
question: Which situation most accurately describes how, following the 2009 pandemic, numerous new swine influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 genotypes with unclear phenotypic effects might arise?
A: Direct acquisition by A(H1N1)pdm09 of the TRIG cassette through non-segmented recombination events that replace the viral genome, eliminating the possibility of reassortment-driven constellation diversity
B: A single introduction of human A(H1N1)pdm09 into swine followed by gradual accumulation of point mutations under strong purifying selection, producing limited genomic diversity but high antigenic shift
C: Reassortment restricted to exchanges among human seasonal A(H1N1)pdm09 viruses within human hosts, with subsequent clonal expansion in swine without further mixing with swine influenza A viruses
D: Repeated spillback of human A(H1N1)pdm09 into pigs followed by reassortment with diverse swine influenza A lineages, including strains carrying the TRIG internal gene cassette, yielding many genome constellations

question:
Contextual materials: Norovirus, an ssRNA + virus of the family Caliciviridae, is a leading disease burden in humans worldwide, causing an estimated 600 million cases of acute gastroenteritis every year. Since the discovery of norovirus in the faeces of swine in Japan in the 1990s, swine norovirus has been reported in several countries on several continents. The identification of the human-associated GII.4 genotype in swine has raised questions about this animal species as a reservoir of norovirus with zoonotic potential, even if species-specific P-types are usually detected in swine.
question: Which option best reflects the epidemiological and molecular significance of finding the human-associated norovirus genotype GII.4 in pigs, considering that pigs generally carry species-specific P-types?
A: It suggests swine may act as a reservoir with zoonotic potential, potentially via reassortment-like exchange of capsid genotypes despite the absence of genome segmentation in ssRNA(+) noroviruses
B: It demonstrates that swine noroviruses must be DNA viruses, since maintaining a human-associated genotype in an animal host would require reverse transcription into a stable provirus
C: It supports the possibility of zoonotic potential or interspecies spillover signals, creating concern even if polymerase (P-type) lineages in swine are usually host-restricted
D: It indicates swine are unlikely to contribute to human disease because species-specific P-types in swine preclude any meaningful cross-species transmission of GII.4

question:
Contextual materials: ASF virus (ASFV) is a complex, large, icosahedral multi-enveloped DNA virus, classified as the only member of the family Asfarviridae, genus Asfivirus (Dixon et al., 2005). ASFV genome encodes a significant number of viral enzymes, viral transcription factors and immune homologues among others. The viral particle contains 54 structural proteins. Nearly, a hundred proteins have been identified on the target cells during ASFV infection, particularly in pig macrophages (Dixon, Chapman, Netherton, & Upton, 2013). Both, structural and infection-related proteins can regulate, inhibit and modulate essential and non-essential mechanisms affecting virus replication, virus particle production and apoptosis. Some of them are based on the inhibition of host transcription factors, the interferon response or several immune cell subsets, to evade host immune system.
question: Which option best describes African swine fever virus (ASFV) in a manner that aligns with its classification and reflects the functional significance of its genome and the proteins present in its virion?
A: ASFV is the sole member of Asfarviridae (genus Asfivirus) and is a large, complex icosahedral multi-enveloped DNA virus whose genome encodes numerous enzymes, transcription factors, and immune homologues that support immune evasion and modulation of replication and apoptosis.
B: ASFV is a papillomavirus-like circular dsDNA virus whose icosahedral capsid is dominated by L1/L2 proteins, and its immune evasion is primarily achieved by antigenic drift in capsid genes rather than encoded immune homologues.
C: ASFV belongs to a multi-member family within Asfarviridae and is characterized by a minimal set of structural proteins (<10), with most host modulation arising indirectly from macrophage cytokine dysregulation rather than direct inhibition of host transcription factors or interferon responses.
D: ASFV is an enveloped RNA virus classified within Asfarviridae; its limited coding capacity necessitates reliance on host polymerases and precludes encoding substantial viral transcription factors or immune-modulatory homologues.

question:
Contextual materials: Currently, African swine fever (ASF) constitutes the biggest threat faced by the world pork industry. The causative agent, African swine fever (ASFV), is a large and complex double-stranded DNA virus belonging to the Asfarviridae family [1]. ASFV affects domestic pigs and wild boars as well as other African suids. Clinical signs during infection vary considerably from acute forms, with mortality rates up to  $90 - 100\%$  in domestic pigs and wild boar to inapparent infections in bushpigs (Potamochoerus sp.) and warthogs (Phacochoerus sp.). The latter are involved in the sylvatic cycle with a soft tick vector Ornithodoros sp. [2]. The mature viral particle has an icosahedral morphology with a size range of  $180 - 200 \mathrm{~nm}$  in diameter and is composed of multiple layers (nucleoprotein core, core shell, inner envelope, viral capsid and external envelope when the virus egresses from the cell) [3]. The genome is a double-stranded DNA molecule located in the nucleoprotein core, with approximately 170 to  $193 \mathrm{kbp}$  codifying for 151 to 167 open reading frames (ORFs). Most differences in genome size are associated with the gain or loss of members of multigene families (MGF) [4,5].
question: A virus newly recovered from domestic pigs has an ~190 nm icosahedral virion with multiple layers (nucleoprotein core, core shell, inner envelope, capsid, and an outer envelope gained during cell exit). It carries a ~185 kbp double-stranded DNA genome encoding about 160 ORFs, and related isolates mainly vary due to increases or decreases in multigene family (MGF) genes. Considering these characteristics—along with transmission in a sylvatic cycle involving Ornithodoros soft ticks and typically subclinical infection in African suids—which virus is the best match?
A: Classical swine fever virus, an enveloped positive-sense ssRNA pestivirus whose genome-length variation is primarily due to polymerase slippage in UTRs
B: Foot-and-mouth disease virus, a non-enveloped icosahedral positive-sense ssRNA virus whose particle size and layered architecture match large dsDNA viruses
C: Porcine circovirus 2, a small non-enveloped circular ssDNA virus where size variation reflects capsid gene recombination rather than multigene families
D: African swine fever virus (ASFV), a large dsDNA virus in Asfarviridae with genome-size variation driven largely by multigene families

question:
Contextual materials: The evolution of pandemic viruses requires a 'perfect ecological storm' in which multiple host populations perform at least two key functions: (a) generating and sustaining viral diversity and (b) transmitting viral diversity to humans. Reservoir hosts serve the former role, harboring high viral genetic diversity but with low rates of direct contact with humans (such as wild birds, bats, or rodents) (5). Intermediary hosts are typically livestock or domestic animals that serve the latter role: they often harbor only a subset of the viral diversity that circulates in reservoir hosts yet are capable of transmitting viral diversity to humans via high rates of contact (1). In the United States, commercial swine serve as reservoir hosts, and exhibition swine effectively serve as intermediary hosts. Commercial swine are produced for food production exclusively in a year-round system that is highly conducive to the evolution and sustained transmission of genetically diverse viruses (6), but less conducive to zoonotic transmission, with high biosecurity and less frequent contact with humans. In contrast, exhibition swine effectively serve as intermediary hosts because they are raised and exhibited in a system with low biosecurity that maximizes human contact (7, 8) but purges genetic diversity and host immunity at the end of the summer show season when exhibition swine finish showing and a new cohort of swine are raised for next year (9). A production system in which commercial and exhibition swine are occasionally raised together provides opportunities for genetically diverse viruses to end up at county fairs and find their way into humans (10-12).
question: In a two-host system, one population maintains extensive viral genetic diversity but rarely interacts directly with humans, while the other undergoes recurring seasonal replacement that diminishes viral diversity yet frequently contacts humans. Which combination of host roles and underlying mechanisms is most likely to enable a genetically diverse virus to spill over into humans?
A: Reservoir: seasonal turnover purges diversity; Intermediary: year-round production sustains diversity; spillover follows increased biosecurity breaches in the reservoir
B: Reservoir: high-contact setting sustains diversity via frequent zoonoses; Intermediary: low-contact setting preserves diversity via reduced selection; spillover is driven by isolation between the populations
C: Reservoir: year-round system sustains genetically diverse viruses; Intermediary: low-biosecurity high-contact system amplifies transmission of a subset; spillover occurs when mixing allows reservoir diversity to enter the intermediary
D: Reservoir: maintains diversity but primarily transmits directly to humans; Intermediary: generates novel diversity through end-of-season immunity; spillover occurs without inter-population mixing

question:
Contextual materials: Swine hepatitis E virus (swine HEV) belongs to the species Orthohepevirus A within the genus Orthohepevirus in the family Hepeviridae. Four different genotypes of swine HEV within the species Orthohepevirus A have been identified so far from domesticated and wild swine population: genotypes 3 (HEV-3) and 4 (HEV-4) swine HEVs are zoonotic and infect humans, whereas HEV-5 and HEV-6 are only identified from swine. Pigs are natural reservoir for HEV, consumption of raw or undercooked pork is an important route of foodborne HEV transmission. question:
Contextual materials: There are many reasons why an ASFV vaccine has proved so elusive. First, the virus itself is large and complex with many proteins, some of which have adapted to evade the immune response of the host (Powell and others 1996, Sanchez and others 2013). The virus is also variable, with many genotypes in existence and limited or no cross-protection across genotypes (Bastos and others 2003). Second, the host-immune response to the virus is complex, with only partial protection produced by neutralising antibodies (Escri-ano and others 2013), with the cell mediated arm of the immune system (T cells) playing an important complementary role (Oura and others 2005, Takamatsu and others 2013). Simple inactivation or attenuation of the virus does not produce sufficient protection, and the administration of individual recombinant proteins and/or DNA only gives partial protection (Argilaguet and others 2013).

C: A small, antigenically stable virus whose envelope proteins are poorly immunogenic, making neutralising antibodies irrelevant and leaving only innate immunity as a protective mechanism

question:
Contextual materials: Pancreas disease (PD) is a viral disease that affects farmed salmonids in the seawater phase in Ireland, Norway and Scotland. It is caused by Salmonid alphavirus (SAV), a member of the genus Alphavirus, family Togaviridae, a spherical, enveloped, single-stranded positive-sense RNA virus of approximately  $60 - 70\mathrm{nm}$  in diameter with a  $12\mathrm{kb}$  genome (Strauss & Strauss 1994; Weston et al. 1999; Powers et al. 2001). The genome contains two open reading frames with the  $5^{\prime}$  two-thirds of the genome encoding the four nonstructural proteins (nsP1-4), while the four capsid glycoproteins (E1, E2, E3 and 6K) are encoded in the  $3^{\prime}$  end of the genome (Strauss & Strauss 1994; Powers et al. 2001). Six SAV subtypes have been identified based on the nucleic acid sequences encoding proteins E2 and nsP3 (Fringuelli et al. 2008), namely SAV subtypes 1-6. The SAV subtype 2 is divided into two subgroups: the freshwater variant, SAV2 FW, and the marine variant, marine SAV2. SAV2 FW typically causes sleeping disease (SD) in freshwater-reared rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss (Walbaum)) in England, Scotland and a number of countries on the European mainland (Graham et al. 2007a). Marine SAV2 typically causes PD in seawater-reared Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar L.) and rainbow trout. This paper focuses on PD, therefore only covering SAV infections in the seawater phase. The current distribution of SAV subtypes is shown in Fig. 1. SAV 1, 4, and 6 have been identified in conjunction with Irish PD outbreaks, while SAV 1, 4, 5 and marine SAV2 have been associated with Scottish outbreaks (Fringuelli et al. 2008). SAV 3 has so far only been detected in Norway (Hodneland et al. 2005; Weston et al. 2005; Karlsen et al. 2006, 2014; Jansen et al. 2010a), where outbreaks caused by marine SAV2 are also seen (Hjortaas et al. 2013, 2016).

question:
Contextual materials: Aeromonas dhakensis is increasingly recognised to be an important pathogen responsible for disease losses in warm-water aquaculture and, similar to several other Aeromonas species, it can infect humans. Knowledge of A. dhakensis is accumulating, but this species remains relatively underinvestigated compared to its close relative, Aeromonas hydrophila. The significance of A. dhakensis may have been overlooked in disease events of aquatic animals due to issues with reliable identification. Critical to appreciating the importance of this pathogen is the application of dependable molecular tools that enable accurate identification and discrimination from A. hydrophila and other motile aeromonads. This review aims to synthesise the key literature on A. dhakensis, particularly with relevance to aquaculture, including knowledge of the bacterium derived from disease case studies in aquatic hosts. Identification methods and strain phylogeny are discussed, with accurate detection important for prompt diagnosis and for distinguishing strains with heightened virulence. Increasing evidence suggests that A. dhakensis may be more virulent than A. hydrophila and correct identification is required to determine the zoonotic risks posed, which includes concerns for antibiotic-resistant strains. This review provides an impetus to improve species identification in the future and screen strain collections of presumptive Aeromonas spp. retrospectively to reveal the true prevalence and impact of A. dhakensis in aquaculture, the environment, and healthcare settings.

question:
Contextual materials: Recent global health assessments have identified FZT as among the most important (and neglected) parasitic zoonotic diseases [1-7]. Along with bacteria and viruses, FZT can be important causes of illnesses in humans, ranging from mild gastroenteritis to life-threatening disease [8]. These infections occur in humans and other reservoir hosts as a result of ingesting raw or improperly cooked fish that are infected with the metacercaria stage of the zoonotic trematodes (or flukes). The liver flukes Opisthorchis viverrini, O. felineus, and Clonorchis sinensis are notable for causing chronic inflammation of the hepatobiliary system, which in chronic infections may lead to cholangiocarcinoma [9]. Infections with intestinal FZT (mainly species of Heterophyidae such as Haplorchis spp.) and Echinostomatidae (e.g., Echinochasmus spp.) may cause intestinal inflammation, diarrhea, and invasion of the heart, brain, and spinal cord by parasite eggs [10,11]. Other important intestinal flukes are Metagonimus spp., Centrocestus spp.,stellantchasmus falcatus,and Procerovum varium [11].

question:
Contextual materials: Bacterial gill disease (BGD) is a common and occasionally devastating disease that affects numerous cultured fish species throughout the world (Starliper & Schill 2012). Outbreaks of BGD tend to occur when environmental conditions deteriorate, and opportunistic pathogens can more readily cause overt disease (Bullock 1972; Schachte 1983). The putative causative agent, Flavobacterium branchiophilum, has been shown to induce BGD under laboratory conditions (e.g. Lumsden et al. 1995; Ostland et al. 1995); however, diagnosis of BGD in the field is generally carried out through light microscopy and/or observation of clinical signs. Therefore, the identity of the bacterial specie(s) present on the gills of BGD-affected fish in culture settings is most often based on visual assessment alone. The observed bacteria using microscopy are presumed to be  $F$  branchiophilum based on organism morphology (numerous long, thin rods; Fig. 1.), with this presumption supported by previous BGD research (e.g. Byrne et al. 1995; Ostland et al. 1997; Derksen, Ostland & Ferguson 1998) and various  $F.$  branchiophilumspecific diagnostic approaches that have been developed. The latter include ELISA (MacPhee et al. 1995), IFAT (Heo, Kasai & Wakabayashi 1990), and PCR (Toyama, Kita & Wakabayashi 1996).

question:
Contextual materials: Currently, aquaculture is the fastest growing animal food sector worldwide (FAO 2014). However, fish and shellfish production is limited by several emerging diseases caused by viruses, bacteria, fungi, oomycetes, amoebas and other ectoparasites. Bacterial fish diseases are typically addressed by antibiotics (Romero et al. 2012; Cabello et al. 2013), viral diseases by vaccination (Evensen and Leong 2013) and parasitic diseases by chemical treatment (Burridge et al. 2010). However, the risk of antibiotic resistance development and the transfer of antibiotic resistance genes to other animal pathogens, as well as concerns for environmental impact and consumer safety, have stimulated the need for new sustainable control measures (Brandt et al. 2015). Vaccination is a sustainable control measure, but various viral and bacterial fish diseases, and more specifically fungal and oomycete diseases, cannot yet be controlled by vaccination (Evensen and Leong 2013; Dhar, Manna and Thomas Allnutt 2014; Holvold et al. 2014). In addition, the oral delivery of efficacious and safe vaccines remains a challenge, partly due to antigen breakdown of oral vaccines in the harsh gastric environment, the high tolerogenic gut environment and inadequate vaccine design (reviewed in Embregts and Forlenza 2016). Additional strategies for sustainable disease control include breeding for disease resistance (Gjedrem 2012), the use of plant extracts as prebiotics (Akhter et al. 2015; Van Hai 2015) and augmentation or introduction of beneficial microorganisms.

B: Rapid antigen degradation in the gastric environment, a tolerogenic gut milieu that dampens immune responses, and shortcomings in vaccine design
C: High antigen stability in the stomach, excessive inflammatory priming in the gut, and the inability to formulate vaccines without antibiotics
D: Dominant resistance-gene transfer driven primarily by vaccines, insufficient capsid formation in orally delivered antigens, and low pathogen diversity in aquaculture systems

Contextual materials: The majority of MCTs originate in the dermis and extend into the subcutis, but there is a subset that is restricted to the subcutaneous fat and are classified as a subtype in their own right – subcutaneous MCTs. This is determined on the basis of location within the subcutaneous tissue and no invasion of the dermis, although multifocal extension of low numbers of mast cells around the base of hair follicles or mast cells infiltrating the underlying panniculus musculature is allowed, as long as the bulk of the tumour is within the subcutaneous tissue. There is no supporting evidence for the usefulness of grading these tumours with any of the cutaneous grading systems, but a few studies have looked at the prognostication of subcutaneous MCTs as a separate entity. Tumours should be assessed based on the growth pattern, presence of multinucleation (defined as more than 1 nuclei per cell, present if there was at least 1 multinucleated cell in 10 HPFs [400×]), and the mitotic count. The strongest effect on clinical outcome appears to be mitotic activity. Subcutaneous tumours are more effectively controlled by surgery alone than their cutaneous counterparts. Surgery is curative for the majority of these tumours.

question:
Contextual materials: Malassezia dermatitis can be treated with topical or systemic antifungals alone or in combination. Combination therapy may lead to faster resolution of disease. Topical therapy alone or pulse dosing of oral therapy can be used as prevention once infection and underlying disease are better controlled. Topical therapy is available as a shampoo, spray, wipe, mousse, or gel and should contain 2% chlorhexidine with 2% miconazole or ketoconazole, 3–4% chlorhexidine when it is the sole active ingredient, 1–2% miconazole, or 2% climbazole. A frequency of two to three times per week for three to four weeks is recommended for active infection; this can be reduced to one to two times per week for maintenance and prevention. The author prefers shampoo for generalized infections and wipes for facial fold, claw fold, and interdigital treatment. Ketoconazole (5–10 mg/kg/day) and itraconazole (5–10 mg/kg/day) are the most effective oral therapeutic options for dogs. Overall itraconazole is better tolerated, although some canine patients will have gastrointestinal upset (vomiting, inappetence, and diarrhea) with both oral medications. Fluconazole (5–10 mg/kg/day) is another option and may have fewer adverse effects and drug interactions, but may not be as reliable for Malassezia treatment. Terbinafine (30 mg/kg/day) does not achieve high stratum corneum or sebum concentrations and is not as effective for surface infections (Gimmler et al. 2015). The duration of oral therapy varies, but most cases are given daily therapy for 20–30 days, then if pulse therapy is needed, the dose is continued one to three times a week. The compounded versions of any of the azole medications should be avoided due to poor bioavailability of these formulations.

question:
Contextual materials: The cuticle is an extremely thin proteinaceous layer, which plugs the entry to the shell pores and regulates the permeability to gases, liquids, and particles (Board and Halls 1973; Mortola 2009). The cuticle is deposited by the epithelial cells lining the hen uterus during the last 5 h before oviposition (Nys et al. 1999). The cuticle thickness on the eggs of domestic hens varies from 0.5 to 12.8 μm and can have an uneven or patchy distribution on the eggshell surface (Board and Halls 1973). Theoretically, the cuticle subserves diverse functions, varying from reducing water loss to the first lines of defense against bacterial penetration by blocking the external surface of pores (Kulshreshtha et al. 2018). It has been shown that cuticle composition is correlated with the hen age and egg ­freshness, and this information could be useful to design strategies to evaluate and reduce the contamination risks during egg processing (Rodríguez-­Navarro et al. 2013). The cuticle consists of 85–87% protein, 3.5–4.4% carbohydrates, 2.5–3.5% lipids, and 3.5% ash (Nys et al. 1999; Rose-­Martel et al. 2012; Rodríguez-­Navarro et al. 2013). It is recommended to lightly brush off any organic debris from eggs, rather than washing them, to prevent damage to the cuticle. If eggs are to be cleaned then it is recommended to use water that is warmer, specifically 20 °F (11 °C) warmer, than the egg so that contaminants are not drawn into the egg via vacuum action through the pores in the shell (Damerov 1994).

B: Wash the egg in water ~11 °C warmer than the egg and avoid aggressive scrubbing that could abrade the cuticle
C: Wash the egg in water ~11 °C cooler than the egg to prevent thermal expansion of pore contents and then dry rapidly
D: Soak the egg in room-temperature water for several minutes to equilibrate pressures across the shell before brushing

question:
Contextual materials: Certain liver diseases that affect the urea cycle, particularly acquired or inherited defects in any one of the five urea cycle enzymes, may have severe consequences for the mammalian organism since there are no alternative pathways for urea biosynthesis. For example, arginosuccinate synthetase deficiency, although rare, has been reported in dogs. Patients exhibit protein intolerance, hyperammonemia, and a hepatoencephalopathy that leads to CNS depression, coma and death if left untreated. Treatment generally requires measures to control the hepatoencephalopathy, including a low-protein diet and oral antibiotics. Vascular abnormalities that shunt portal blood into the systemic circulation without perfusing hepatic sinusoids (i.e., portalcaval shunts) compromise the liver's ability to detoxify \(NH_{3}\) through the urea cycle, and many other liver diseases are known as well to result in decreased urea cycle enzyme activity with hyperammonemia.

B: Defective urea-cycle enzymes mainly impair hepatic gluconeogenesis, with neurologic signs arising secondarily from hypoglycemia
C: Ammonia detoxification can be rerouted through redundant hepatic pathways, but only if portal blood bypasses hepatic sinusoids
D: Hyperammonemia results primarily from bacterial urease in the gut, so hepatic enzyme defects are usually clinically silent without infection

question:
Contextual materials: A Wood’s lamp examination is one of the simplest screening tools for dermatophytosis, but is only useful for some strains of \(M.\) canis, since only \(M.\) canis produces the classic emerald or apple-­green fluorescence of the hair shaft (Figure 9). In the hands of a skilled user, a Wood’s lamp will detect positive \(M.\) canis infection approximately 70–100% of the time (Moriello et al. 2017). Unfortunately, lint, skin surface crust and debris, and topical medications can cause similar fluorescence, which can lead to false positive results. Glowing hairs should be plucked and examined under the microscope for confirmation of the diagnosis. Hairs treated with appropriate topical therapy will not cease to fluoresce; but only the infected portion will glow, so a simple trick for monitoring response to treatment is to watch for loss of fluorescence as hairs grow out. Direct microscopic evaluation of infected hairs is another reliable diagnostic tool in the hands of a skilled examiner. Hairs from the edge of a lesion are plucked and placed on a slide with mineral oil and a coverslip. They are evaluated for the presence of hyphae and arthrospores on 100× power. Lowering and closing the condenser can increase contrast, which allows spores and hyphae to stand out. Infected hairs tend to be larger in diameter with a fuzzy or irregular outline, and they lack a clear demarcation between the cortex and the medulla. Most dermatophyte infections in animals produce an ectothrix distribution of arthrospores: coccoid elements surrounding the outside of the hair shaft. Hyphae will be seen growing within the hair shaft (Figure 6.10). Use of a Wood’s lamp to highlight actively glowing hairs on the microscope slide can assist in identification of M. canis.

question:
Contextual materials: Cutaneous xanthomas are rare granulomatous skin lesions that occur in both dogs and cats because of an abnormality in lipid metabolism. High-­fat diets and diabetes mellitus can be associated with these skin lesions in both species and hereditary hyperlipoproteinemia has been seen in cats with xanthomas. Patients may present with white or yellow papules, nodules, or plaques with surrounding erythema. The lesions may ulcerate with time and can be pruritic or painful. Typical locations involved include the head, distal limbs, feet, and bony prominences. Differential diagnoses for cutaneous xanthomas include sterile nodular panniculitis, sterile granuloma/pyogranuloma syndrome, and neoplasia. Diagnosis is made by histopathology, which reveals foamy macrophages with multinucleated giant cells and lipid lakes throughout the dermis. If the patient is a cat, remember to check lipid levels on a serum chemistry panel. Tissue samples from nodular lesions should also be submitted for bacterial and fungal cultures and secondary infections should be addressed. Deep skin scrapings and fungal culture should also be performed if the patient is pruritic or has spreading lesions. Treatment involves feeding a prescription low-­fat diet as well as managing any underlying disease such as diabetes. Clients should be informed that removing the lesions surgically without correcting the underlying cause will result in recurrence; however, it may be prudent to remove lesions that are on pressure point areas to relieve any discomfort.

Diagnosis is made by histopathology, which reveals foamy macrophages with multinucleated giant cells and lipid lakes throughout the dermis. If the patient is a cat, remember to check lipid levels on a serum chemistry panel. Tissue samples from nodular lesions should also be submitted for bacterial and fungal cultures and secondary infections should be addressed. Deep skin scrapings and fungal culture should also be performed if the patient is pruritic or has spreading lesions. Treatment involves feeding a prescription low-­fat diet as well as managing any underlying disease such as diabetes. Clients should be informed that removing the lesions surgically without correcting the underlying cause will result in recurrence; however, it may be prudent to remove lesions that are on pressure point areas to relieve any discomfort.

Contextual materials: The brachial wing vein (basilic or cutaneous ulnar vein) is the most common site for blood collection in an adult chicken (Figure 12). It can be accessed near the elbow. Contextual materials: Mobilization of glucose from glycogen stores requires two reactions: shortening of the nonreducing ends of α -1,4 glycosidic chains by a regulatory phosphorylase, and disassembly of the \(\alpha-1,6\) branch points by a non-regulatory debranching enzyme. The first reaction adds inorganic phosphate (Pi) rather than \(H_{2} O\) across the glycosidic bond, resulting in the release of Glc-1-P which can then be converted to Glc-6-P by PGM. The second reaction removes a free glucose residue from glycogen which can be quickly phosphorylated to Glc-6-P and used in the Embden-Meyerhoff pathway (EMP), or released by liver tissue into blood (Fig. 23-4). Additionally, Glc-6-P may also be dephosphorylated by hepatic Glu-6-Pase, and released as free glucose into blood. Approximately 90% of glycogen degradation results in Glc-1-P formation through reaction one above, and 10% in free glucose formation through reaction two.

question:
Contextual materials: The dorsal mesogastrium attaches to the greater curvature of the stomach and grows caudally as a net-­like cover over the ventral aspect of the intestines; it becomes the greater omentum. The greater omentum actually comprises two layers like a pouch with a parietal or superficial part and a visceral or deep part. The two layers extend cranially to the transverse colon, where they pass either side and form attachments to the pancreas and the spleen. The enclosed cavity is the omental bursa and has only one entry, the epiploic foramen, located caudomedial to the caudate lobe of the liver. The epiploic foramen is dorsal to the caudal vena cava and dorsomedial to the hepatic portal vein. It is slit-­like and measures about 4 cm in the dog.

question:
Contextual materials: The actual mechanism by which the descent of the testes occurs has been the subject of debate for many years and the object of much research. It is clear that there is considerable variation between species not least because of anatomical and physiological differences. Endocrine factors certainly appear to have a significant role. The requirement for the descent of the mammalian testes to an extra-­abdominal location is due to the need to lower the temperature by 2–3°C of the body temperature for spermatogenesis (see Section 5). However, the testes of the elephant and the hyrax are intra-­abdominal. Inguinal passage occurs at about 120 days of pregnancy in the ox, 80 days in the sheep and 90 days in the pig. In the horse, however, the testis is drawn to the inguinal ring, but at 100–120 days the foetal gonad starts to enlarge rapidly and is unable to pass through the inguinal canal. The gonads reach maximum size at about 210–240 days of pregnancy. The testes then undergo shrinkage until inguinal passage is possible at about 300 days, although some distortion of the testes is still necessary. By the time the foal is born the testes are normally through the inguinal canal.
question: A veterinarian is evaluating typical fetal testicular descent in domestic species. Which option best explains both the correct timing and the underlying reason that inguinal passage occurs much later in the horse compared with the ox, sheep, or pig?
A: In the horse, inguinal passage is delayed until about 210–240 days because the testes remain intra-abdominal to preserve higher temperature for spermatogenesis; in the ox, sheep, and pig passage occurs near term for the same reason.
B: In the horse, inguinal passage occurs at about 100–120 days when the testes are drawn to the inguinal ring; in the ox, sheep, and pig it occurs later because their gonads enlarge too rapidly to traverse the canal until they shrink.
C: In the horse, inguinal passage is delayed until after birth because the testes reach maximum size at about 300 days; in the ox, sheep, and pig passage occurs at about 120 days because their testes never enlarge substantially in utero.
D: In the horse, inguinal passage is delayed until about 300 days because rapid fetal gonadal enlargement around 100–120 days prevents transit through the inguinal canal until subsequent shrinkage; in the ox, sheep, and pig passage occurs earlier (about 120, 80, and 90 days, respectively).

question:
Contextual materials: The characterization of nephron segments varies among fishes because some species lack some segments, and also the cellular structure can be different within the same portion for different species, especially because the major function of this organ is directly correlated with fish habitat under adaptation to the water of different salinities. Some fish lack renal corpuscles (RCs) altogether and their kidneys are termed aglomerular. This type is predominantly found in marine species and euryhaline fishes in seawater, such as toadfish (family Batracoididae), anglerfish (order Lophiiformes), sea horses (genus Hippocampus), and needlefish (family Belonidae). Teleosts, such as eels, salmonids, and ostariophysids (e.g., carps and catfishes) possess a long multisegmental nephron, whereas, in marine teleosts of different orders, such as percids (family Percidae), killifish (order Cyprinodontiformes), flounder (order Pleuronectiformes), and sticklebacks (family Gasterosteidae), the nephron is shorter because the distal segment is absent.
question: A scientist examines differences in fish nephron structure and observes that some taxa typically have kidneys without renal corpuscles, whereas others have an extended, multisegment nephron. Which option correctly pairs each nephron type with the taxa most commonly showing it and the habitat (salinity) it is most associated with?
A: Long multisegmental nephron — characteristic of marine percids, killifish, flounder, and sticklebacks because renal corpuscles are absent
B: Short nephron due to absent distal segment — typical of salmonids and ostariophysids such as carps and catfishes, especially in freshwater
C: Aglomerular kidney lacking renal corpuscles — predominantly marine or euryhaline fishes in seawater such as toadfish, anglerfish, sea horses, and needlefish
D: Aglomerular kidney lacking renal corpuscles — characteristic of eels, salmonids, and ostariophysids, particularly in marine teleosts with absent distal segments

question:
Contextual materials: Macrolide antibiotics and similar molecules are active against gram-­positive (S. aureus, Streptococcus spp.) and atypical pathogens (Chlamydia spp., Mycoplasma spp.), but have a limited spectrum against gram-­negative organisms. Macrolides are ineffective against enteric gram-­ negative bacilli such as Escherichia coli and are ineffective against P. aeruginosa. They are active against fastidious gram-­negative organisms (Campylobacter spp., Borrelia spp., Bordetella spp., Brucella spp., Pasteurella spp., Haemophilus spp., H. pylori) and spirochetes (Treponema pallidum). Some differences exist in the overlapping spectrums of each macrolide antibiotic. Macrolides and their relatives are bacteriostatic agents that block bacterial protein synthesis. Macrolides may also inhibit production of bacterial virulence factors (Kanoh and Rubin 2010), may have anti-­inflammatory properties (Rubin and Tamaoki 2000; Culić et al. 2001), immunomodulatory activity (Piacentini et al. 2007), and effects on cell signaling (Clapham 2007). Resistance to macrolides and related compounds occurs in three ways (Nakajima 1999; Leclercq and Courvalin 2002). The first is target site modification by methylation or other mutation that prevents binding of the drug to the ribosomal target. For example, the A2059G mutation confers high-­level resistance to macrolides such as erythromycin and azithromycin, moderate resistance to clarithromycin and clindamycin, but no resistance to streptogramins (Tait-­Kamradt et al. 2000; Canu et al. 2002). The second is efflux mediated by physiologic pumps that actively pump the drug out of the bacterial cell and are encoded by the mef (A) gene with efflux driven by proton motive force (Clancy et al. 1996). The third is drug inactivation by degradation from hydrolysis of the macrolide lactone ring or drug modification related to macrolide phosphorylation. Macrolide inactivation is rare and less common than other mechanisms of macrolide resistance.

C: High-level resistance to erythromycin and azithromycin; moderate resistance to clarithromycin and clindamycin; no resistance to streptogramins
D: Resistance limited to streptogramins with preserved susceptibility to erythromycin, azithromycin, clarithromycin, and clindamycin due to compensatory binding

Contextual materials: The canal of the AO of guppy contains mucous cells that stained slight violet with PAS-AB stain, also the apical border of support cells was AB-posi­ tive (Figure 19B). The ampullary pores (APs) are distributed throughout the head and lined with a single layer of squamous cells (Figure 7.19C). The transverse-section through the AO shows that it composes of a sac of fusiform receptor cells that lie below the AP (Figure 7.19D). The superficial and deep (canal) neuromasts of guppy differ from those present in red-tail shark. The canals neuromast is widely distributed in the head and operculum and open at intervals to the exterior and surrounded by dermal bone (DB). The CN is lined by two layers of sensory cells with apical microvilli and the opposite side of the canal is lined with a simple squamous epithelium containing AB-positive mucous cells as these canals are filled with fluid (water and mucous secretion), which allow transmission of vibrations to the neuromasts through the skin pores. A bundle of nerve fibers lied below the canal and passed between the DBs (Figure 7.20A). The CN of guppies is surrounded by an osseous coat, while that of red-tail shark is supported by a fibrous coat and this may be an adaptive means against squeezing the contents of the canal by high water pressures in the bottom.

question:
Contextual materials: Injury to the paw or digits is a frequent cause of a non‐weight‐bearing lameness. As many dogs are sensitive to paw palpation and tend to withdraw the limb during palpation, paw and digit palpation should be performed with other joints (carpal and elbow) in relatively flexed positions. Examination of the paw generally consists of assessing each digit, including the nail and nail bed. Common sources of lame­ ness arising from these sites include: Split nails, Nail‐bed tumors, Fracture/luxation of the phalanges, Infection, Penetrating foreign bodies, Pad lacerations. Nails are inspected for signs of wear, which may indicate digit dragging due to neurologic disorders (Figure 1). Careful palpation of the digits and manipulation of the joints in flexion and extension, while observing for evidence of pain or swelling, is a sensitive method to deter­ mine whether any part of the paw is a source of pain.
question: When assessing a dog suspected of having a paw-related non-weight-bearing lameness, which examination technique most effectively increases diagnostic sensitivity while reducing limb withdrawal in a patient that is sensitive to paw palpation?
A: Avoid direct digit palpation; instead, infer paw pain by inspecting nails only, since wear reliably localizes lesions causing lameness
B: Palpate the paw and digits while maintaining the carpal and elbow joints in relatively flexed positions, assessing each digit (including nail and nail bed) followed by digit palpation and joint manipulation through flexion–extension while observing for pain or swelling
C: Begin with maximal digit abduction and sustained extension to elicit crepitus, then examine nails and pads only if swelling is absent
D: Perform forceful extension of the carpus and elbow to stabilize the limb, then rapidly palpate the paw to identify focal pain

question:
Contextual materials: Nursery pigs and growers very often show sneezing and catarrhal nasal discharge as the first clinical sign after an infection with M. hyorhinis. They might exhibit fewer, reduced feed intake and depression for up to 10–14 days, before they recover in case of no further complications. In case of a concurrent infection with a primary respiratory pathogen, M. hyorhinis is also found in the lower airways and might contribute to the pathogenesis of pneumonia, and thereby to the severity of coughing and dyspnoea. When the infection becomes systemic, M. hyorhinis can cause pleuritis, which further enhances the respiratory symptoms attributed to pneumonia provoked by a primary respiratory pathogen. Apart from this, pigs often demonstrate a pathological posture with their back curved upwards due to peritonitis and they suffer from pericarditis and lameness because of (poly-) arthritis (Fig. 2). In case of polyserositis and polyarthritis, symptoms often last for more than 6 weeks. Suckling pigs and adult pigs seldom suffer from an infection with M. hyorhinis. However, in rare cases, they might exhibit similar symptoms to those observed in nursery and growing pigs.
question: In cases of swine respiratory disease complex, which pattern of clinical progression best indicates that *Mycoplasma hyorhinis* has spread systemically, rather than causing only a short-lived upper respiratory infection or merely worsening pneumonia driven by a primary respiratory pathogen?
A: Similar respiratory signs in suckling and adult pigs occurring commonly and with high attack rate, indicating age-independent susceptibility
B: Prolonged (>6 weeks) syndrome combining pleuritis-associated intensification of respiratory signs with polyserositis and polyarthritis manifested as lameness and a back-curved posture due to peritonitis
C: Coughing and dyspnoea that worsen when a primary respiratory pathogen is present, consistent with M. hyorhinis colonization of lower airways and contribution to pneumonia severity
D: Sneezing and catarrhal nasal discharge with transient depression and reduced feed intake resolving within 10–14 days in the absence of complications

Contextual materials: Paravertebral anaesthesia involves the injection of a local anaesthetic alongside the dorsal and ventral rami of the spinal nerves at T13, L1 and L2 as they emerge from the intervertebral foramina. The technique produces analgesia of the body wall including the parietal peritoneum. The patient remains standing and fully conscious. The GSA neurons that have touch and pain receptors in the body wall are anaesthetised in the localised area. The anaesthetised ventral rami (T13, L1, L2) contain GSE neurons that innervate the striated muscle in the localised region of the body wall. The parasympathetic system does not have any neurons in the thoracolumbar spinal nerves. The sympathetic system does have preganglionic motor neurons within the ventral roots of the thoracolumbar spinal cord. However, the ratio of pre-­ to postganglionic sympathetic neurons is about 1:20 so that the system is capable of a widespread response or a compensation for the anaesthetised neurons. The result is that, whereas the GSA and GSE neurons are effectively anaesthetised, there are plenty of sympathetic GVA neurons to maintain function.
question: During a standing paravertebral block at T13, L1, and L2, the body wall and parietal peritoneum become analgesic, yet visceral autonomic activity remains mostly intact. What is the most appropriate reason for this difference?
A: The block preferentially anesthetizes dorsal roots but spares ventral roots, preventing loss of sympathetic preganglionic output while still abolishing pain transmission
B: Sympathetic postganglionic neurons travel in the dorsal rami at T13–L2 and are therefore unaffected when local anesthetic is deposited alongside the ventral rami
C: Thoracolumbar spinal nerves lack parasympathetic fibers, and the sympathetic pre- to postganglionic divergence (~1:20) permits widespread compensation, leaving sufficient sympathetic GVA activity despite localized blockade of GSA/GSE fibers
D: Visceral pain and autonomic reflex arcs in the thoracolumbar region are predominantly parasympathetic, which are maintained because they originate from the pelvic nerves rather than spinal nerves

question:
Contextual materials: most common infectious ocular disease of sheep. It is called ‘pink eye’ in the UK and ‘contagious ophthalmia’ in other parts of the world. The cause can be either Mycoplasma conjunctivae or Chlamydophila psittaci, or it may be a combination of both. Sheep can get ocular disease in outbreaks of abortion caused by C. psittaci. Equally, C. psittaci can be isolated as a cause of the abortion and there is no ocular disease. There is no doubt that there is a crossover infection between sheep and goats as C. psittaci occurs in wild sheep and goats which act as a reservoir for the infection throughout the world. It is possible that deer may be the reservoir in the UK. Other bacteria causing the disease may be opportunist pathogens; these include E. coli, Moraxella (Branhamella) ovis and S. aureus. Regardless of the cause of the disease, it always shows a sequential pathogenesis. As many animals are likely to be affected, the clinician will see all the phases at one time. Initially there will be inflammation of the sclera, blepharospasm and an increase in lachrymation. This will lead to corneal inflammation and opacity. There may or may not be corneal vascularization. Lastly, there will be corneal ulceration. Treatment is with antibiotic eye ointment. It is important that corticosteroids are not instilled at the same time. Antibiotics may also be given parenterally. Oxytetracyclines are ideal as they appear in the tears and have long-acting formulations. To help reduce the pain and the inflammation, NSAIDs can be given parenterally.
question: When treating a flock outbreak of infectious ocular disease (“pink eye”) in sheep suspected to involve *Mycoplasma conjunctivae* and/or *Chlamydophila psittaci*, which management option provides effective antibiotic coverage at the eye (including via tear secretion) while also avoiding the contraindicated use of topical corticosteroids that can aggravate corneal lesions?
A: Parenteral NSAIDs alone, as they reduce inflammation and thereby interrupt the sequential pathogenesis to ulceration
B: Parenteral oxytetracycline plus topical antibiotic ointment, while avoiding concurrent topical corticosteroids
C: Topical antibiotic ointment only, because systemic antibiotics do not reach the tear film in clinically meaningful concentrations
D: Topical corticosteroids to reduce pain and inflammation plus parenteral penicillin to cover opportunist bacteria

question:
Contextual materials: H. parasuis strains are heterogeneous and exhibit a wide variability in the degree of virulence, from non-virulent to highly virulent strains. Non-virulent strains are commonly found in the upper respiratory tract as part of the normal microbiota of the animals, where do not cause any pathology. These strains are susceptible to the killing action of porcine alveolar macrophages (PAM) and, under normal conditions, are effectively cleared from the lungs (Fig. 4). If these strains reach the lung, they are detected by PAM, which are then activated for an effective phagocytosis and killing. Non-virulent strains are also sensitive to serum, and cannot survive in blood for systemic dissemination. These characteristics explain why non-virulent strains are not able to cause disease in healthy animals and are controlled by the innate immune system. On the opposite side, virulent strains can evade the immune system and cause disease. After the initial colonization of the upper respiratory tract, virulent strains can reach the lung, where they survive due to their ability to resist phagocytosis. After nasal inoculation, virulent strains can be found colonizing not only the nasal mucosa, but also the tracheal mucosa, where they can form biofilm-like structures. When virulent strains reach the lung, they are confronted by PAM. The interaction between virulent \(H.\) parasuis and PAM is limited and macrophage activation is delayed. During lung infection, \(H.\) parasuis adapt its metabolism to survive in the lung environment and express the necessary virulence factors to resist host defences (Fig. 4). Bacterial capsule and two surface proteins from the trimeric autotransporter family, named VtaA8 and VtaA9 (virulence-associated trimeric autotransporters o VtaA), play a role in phagocytosis resistance. Survival of virulent \(H.\) parasuis in the lung induces inflammation, including neutrophil recruitment, which may result in suppurative bronchopneumonia. The study of cellular location of virulent \(H.\) parasuis in the lung has shown that it can be found associated with neutrophils and macrophages, but also with pneumocytes. This later location of \(H.\) parasuis within pneumocytes may serve as a reservoir for persistent infections.
question: Which step-by-step mechanism best accounts for how highly virulent *H. parasuis* moves from colonizing the upper respiratory tract to establishing a persistent lung infection, even in the presence of innate immune defenses?
A: Enhanced susceptibility to PAM killing in the lung is offset by exclusive extracellular replication on pneumocyte surfaces, preventing neutrophil recruitment and limiting inflammation
B: Immediate strong PAM activation drives efficient phagocytic killing, while serum resistance enables rapid bacteremia that seeds pneumocytes as an intracellular refuge
C: Failure to form biofilm-like structures forces reliance on serum sensitivity to avoid complement, enabling survival in blood and subsequent clearance by neutrophils in the lung
D: Biofilm-like growth on tracheal mucosa is followed by delayed PAM activation in the lung; capsule plus VtaA8/VtaA9 promote phagocytosis resistance, inflammation recruits neutrophils, and pneumocyte association provides a reservoir for persistence

question:
Contextual materials: Septic pedal arthritis does occur in small ruminants but it is rare. Antibiotic treatment, even if prolonged, is rarely successful. Welfare must always be considered, and euthanasia is certainly an option for relieving further suffering. Full drainage of the distal phalangeal joint, with subsequent arthrodesis, may be considered, but this will result in a long period of severe pain. Surgical removal of the digit is a more humane option. It is vital that this surgery is not attempted if there is sepsis in the proximal joints, as pain will then persist. If clinicians are in any doubt, radiography should be carried out. Regional anaesthesia can be used. The distal limb can be cleaned but full asepsis is not required. A length of embryotomy wire is placed between the digits. The sawing direction should be at an angle of 45° above the horizontal. The skin, soft tissue and half the second phalanx should be removed. The foot then should be bandaged before removal of the tourniquet. The animal should be given antibiotic and NSAID cover for a minimum of 1 week. The bandage should be removed every third day until clean granulation tissue is seen.
question: When planning surgical digit amputation to treat septic pedal arthritis in a small ruminant, which preoperative finding is the strongest contraindication because it indicates that pain is likely to continue even after the digit is removed?
A: Failure to angle the embryotomy wire cut at 45° above the horizontal
B: Expectation that antibiotic therapy will be required for at least one week postoperatively
C: Radiographic evidence of sepsis extending into proximal joints
D: Inability to maintain full asepsis of the distal limb during preparation

question:
Contextual materials: It is perhaps in the reproductive system where ruminants are most at variance from SACs. Ruminants have an oestrus cycle, with spontaneous ovulation and no follicular wave cycle. SACs do not have an oestrus cycle and are induced ovulators, but they do have a follicular wave cycle. Ruminants copulate in the standing position with ejaculation short and intense. SACs copulate in the prone position and have prolonged ejaculation. The male SAC has a cartilaginous projection on the tip of his penis. This is absent in ruminants. SACs have a diffuse placenta and the fetus is surrounded by an epidermal membrane. Ruminant fetuses do not have such a membrane but have placental cotyledons. SACs are primarily nasal breathers with an elongated soft palate, and mouth breathing in SACs is an extremely serious sign. Ruminants have a short soft palate and can breathe nasally or orally. The kidneys of SACs are smooth and elliptical. Some ruminants have smooth kidneys, e.g. sheep, and some lobed kidneys, e.g. cattle. The female SAC has a suburethral diverticulum at the external urethral orifice. Ruminants have no such diverticulum. SACs have not only unique internal parasites and protozoa, but also share other species of parasite with cattle, sheep and goats. The picture with external parasites is confusing. SACs certainly have unique lice, and they may also have unique mange mites, but the classification is not yet confirmed.
question: Which set of characteristics most reliably differentiates South American camelids (SACs) from ruminants in terms of reproductive physiology, placental structure, breathing patterns, and female urogenital anatomy?
A: Induced ovulation without a follicular wave cycle; placental cotyledons with an epidermal membrane; nasal-or-oral breathing due to an elongated soft palate; no suburethral diverticulum
B: Induced ovulation with a follicular wave cycle; diffuse placenta with an epidermal membrane around the fetus; primarily nasal breathing due to an elongated soft palate where mouth breathing is a grave sign; suburethral diverticulum at the external urethral orifice
C: Spontaneous ovulation without a follicular wave cycle; placental cotyledons with no epidermal membrane; obligate nasal breathing due to a short soft palate; suburethral diverticulum at the external urethral orifice
D: Spontaneous ovulation with a follicular wave cycle; diffuse placenta with an epidermal membrane; nasal-or-oral breathing due to a short soft palate; no suburethral diverticulum

question:
Contextual materials: Hydrophthalmos refers to an unusually enlarged globe, associated with chronically increased IOP secondary to glaucoma. This is synonymous with the term buphthalmos, but as this term indicates that the globe is cow-­sized, which is actually smaller than a horse globe, hydrophthalmos is the preferred term in equids. Hydrophthalmos suggests an enlarged globe, whatever the original size. In adult horses, with glaucoma, globe size increases slowly and is associated with other clinical signs of glaucoma such as corneal edema and endothelial (Haab’s) striae (Figure 14). Vision may be present, reduced, or absent at the time of diagnosis. Vision may return if the increased IOP is controlled, even if mild globe enlargement remains. Congenital glaucoma may also occur. Hydrophthalmos is more rapid in these cases due to the greater elasticity of young globes; however, vision is lost more rapidly and permanently. Hydrophthalmos must be differentiated from exophthalmos (displacement of a normal-­sized globe), and in unilateral disease comparative ultrasound measurements can confirm this.
question: In a horse suspected of having glaucoma, which diagnostic conclusion most reliably differentiates hydrophthalmos (true globe enlargement) from exophthalmos (forward displacement of a normal-sized globe) and most accurately indicates the chance that vision could return?
A: Comparative ultrasonography showing a larger globe than the contralateral eye supports hydrophthalmos; in adult-onset cases vision may partially return if intraocular pressure is controlled, whereas congenital cases tend to lose vision rapidly and permanently due to greater scleral elasticity
B: Comparative ultrasonography showing equal axial globe lengths supports hydrophthalmos; visual recovery is unlikely in adults but common in congenital cases because juvenile eyes remodel after pressure control
C: A normal-sized globe displaced anteriorly is consistent with hydrophthalmos; persistent mild enlargement after pressure control implies irreversible vision loss in adult horses
D: Haab’s striae with corneal edema is more typical of exophthalmos than hydrophthalmos; vision generally improves in congenital cases because globe enlargement is slower in young eyes

question:
Contextual materials: Salmonella typhimurium is found in cattle, sheep, goats, SACs, pigs and (rarely) in poultry worldwide. It will cause enteritis in humans. S. enteritidis is mainly found in poultry worldwide and will also cause enteritis in humans. S. enterica serovar Dublin is mainly found in cattle and rarely causes human enteritis. There are also other Salmonella species/subspecies/serovars causing salmonellosis which are ever present on farms, e.g. S. enterica ssp. diarizonae and serovar Montevideo. Further, there are species-specific salmonellae, e.g. S. pullorum and S. gallinarum, both found in poultry, and S. abortus ovis, found in sheep. These species rarely cause human disease. Most human Salmonella infections are acquired as a result of eating contaminated food. Infection on farms is more commonly acquired by mouth from hands contaminated by infected animals, their bedding and surroundings. In addition to the general safety measures outlined in the Introduction, the following simple precautions will go a long way towards preventing people associated with livestock from becoming infected with salmonellosis: Ensure that anyone with diarrhoea, vomiting or flu-like illness consults a doctor, and informs the doctor if salmonellae have been isolated from livestock. Don’t allow vulnerable people, including children, the elderly, those with a weakened immune system and pregnant women to come into contact with infected animals. Don’t bring infected animals into any room where food is prepared or eaten. Don’t drink raw milk or eat undercooked eggs from the herd/flock when salmonellae have been isolated – even healthy animals may excrete salmonellae.
question: Which situation most strongly indicates the greatest risk of a person catching Salmonella from livestock, considering the usual animal reservoirs and how transmission commonly occurs?
A: A visitor develops enteritis after contact with sheep carrying Salmonella abortus ovis, despite no food exposure
B: A farm worker develops enteritis after hand-to-mouth exposure while cleaning bedding from cattle shedding Salmonella typhimurium
C: A consumer develops enteritis after eating thoroughly cooked eggs from a flock known to have Salmonella pullorum
D: A consumer develops enteritis after eating pasteurized dairy from cattle herds where Salmonella Dublin is endemic

question:
Contextual materials: In normal animals, the dorsal cricoaryten­ oideus muscles contract to abduct the corni­ culate processes of the arytenoids during inspiration, causing opening of the rima glot­ tidis. This muscle is innervated by the recur­ rent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus that originates near the thoracic inlet and loops around the subclavian artery on the right side, or the aorta on the left side, and returns cra­ niad to the larynx. Laryngeal paralysis is recog­ nized as a congenital disorder or heritable disease in some breeds and as an acquired form in older, large breed dogs. Some breeds that develop congenital laryngeal paralysis are affected by a generalized polyneuropathy (Table 1), and in the acquired idiopathic form, several studies have now confirmed the generalized nature of the neurologic deficits. Electromyographic studies and nerve conduc­ tion velocities in peripheral limb musculature of dogs with acquired laryngeal paralysis are suggestive of axonal disease (Jeffrey et al. 2006; Thieman et al. 2010). It has been recognized that affected older, large breed dogs often dis­ play clinical signs and physical examination findings of esophageal dysfunction and decreased proprioceptive placing, supporting a more generalized neurologic defect (Stanley et al. 2010). Laryngeal sensation is also abnor­ mal. This syndrome has been labeled geriatric-­ onset laryngeal paralysis–polyneuropathy (GOLPP).
question: During inspiration in a healthy dog, which specific nerve and muscle action most directly produces abduction of the corniculate processes to widen the rima glottidis, and what is the usual anatomic difference in this nerve’s route on the right versus the left side?
A: Glossopharyngeal nerve to thyroarytenoideus; loops around the subclavian artery bilaterally and returns cranially to open the rima glottidis
B: Superior laryngeal nerve (vagal branch) to cricothyroideus; loops around the aorta on the right and the subclavian artery on the left before returning caudally to the larynx
C: Phrenic nerve to dorsal cricoarytenoideus; descends from the thoracic inlet without vascular looping and terminates at the arytenoids bilaterally
D: Recurrent laryngeal nerve (vagal branch) to dorsal cricoarytenoideus; loops around the subclavian artery on the right and the aorta on the left before returning cranially to the larynx

question:
Contextual materials: The fracture reduction can be achieved either by closed, open, or semi-open method. Reduction of fracture without incising the skin or exposing the bone, through external manipulation, is called closed reduction. The technique involves holding the major bone segments over the skin, separating the impacted broken ends by traction if needed and then aligning them to the near normal anatomical position. Normally, after a closed reduction, fracture is immobilized with an external fixation technique, although in certain internal fixation, reduction can be achieved externally as in fresh cases of incomplete/greenstick fractures of femur in young animals without bone displacement. Closed reduction is generally indicated in fresh lower limb fractures, comprising only two bone pieces with little or no overriding of the bone segments. Closed reduction is done only when the bone segments are easily palpable with less muscular coverage. It reduces the risk of soft tissue trauma from the surgical incision and also the cost of initial treatment.
question: In which clinical situation is closed reduction most clearly the best initial option for managing a fracture?
A: A fresh lower-limb fracture consisting of two major fragments with minimal or no overriding, where the bone ends are easily palpable due to limited muscular coverage
B: A fresh femoral greenstick fracture in a young animal with no displacement, where reduction is achieved externally but internal fixation is routinely required afterward
C: An older fracture with early callus formation and significant displacement, where traction is unlikely to disengage impacted ends without surgical exposure
D: A comminuted diaphyseal fracture with substantial muscular coverage, where accurate alignment requires direct visualization of the fragments

question:
Contextual materials: Copper accumulates in the liver of dogs with chronic hepatopathies and can be seen as a primary cause (primary copper associated hepatopathy) evident in a growing number of breeds. However, it is also seen accumulating secondary to other causes of hepatopathy. Therefore, the finding of copper in and of itself is not diagnostic for a primary copper associated hepatopathy. There is a difference in the quantity and distribution of copper accumulation seen in primary copper associated hepatopathy as opposed to secondary, but in my experience, it can be sometimes difficult to confidently distinguish between the two, particularly if other changes to the hepatic parenchyma are also severe and distort the lobular architecture and/or in Tru­cut biopsies with few intact lobules. It is very important to assess for the presence of copper, as chelating agents are a potential therapeutic option, regardless of whether the accumulation is primary or secondary. Special staining for copper (typically with stains such as rhodanine, or rubeanic acid) is typically performed on canine liver biopsies for this reason. These special stains detect the presence of copper, the distribution (periportal versus centrilobular), and can allow for a subjective assessment of the severity of any such accumulation. Assessment also entails identifying which cells are accumulating the copper (macrophages and/or hepatocytes) and whether its presence is associated with necrotic hepatocytes, and formation of small ‘copper granulomas’.
question: In dogs with chronic hepatopathy, copper can be identified on liver histology using special stains and the results may affect treatment choices. Which option best describes the main diagnostic caveat—namely that copper detection alone does not confirm primary copper-associated hepatopathy—while still supporting why copper staining should be routinely performed on liver biopsy samples?
A: Copper staining can confirm copper presence and zonal distribution, but severe parenchymal distortion or scant intact lobules (e.g., Tru-cut biopsies) can make primary versus secondary accumulation difficult to distinguish; chelation may still be considered either way
B: Copper granulomas form only when copper is secondary to other hepatopathies and therefore exclude a primary copper-associated hepatopathy diagnosis
C: Demonstrating any hepatic copper with rhodanine is sufficient to diagnose primary copper-associated hepatopathy, which uniquely shows periportal hepatocellular copper without macrophage involvement
D: Rubeanic acid staining primarily quantifies total hepatic copper concentration and cannot localize copper to periportal versus centrilobular regions, making it unsuitable for therapeutic decisions

There is a difference in the quantity and distribution of copper accumulation seen in primary copper associated hepatopathy as opposed to secondary, but in my experience, it can be sometimes difficult to confidently distinguish between the two, particularly if other changes to the hepatic parenchyma are also severe and distort the lobular architecture and/or in Tru­cut biopsies with few intact lobules. It is very important to assess for the presence of copper, as chelating agents are a potential therapeutic option, regardless of whether the accumulation is primary or secondary. Special staining for copper (typically with stains such as rhodanine, or rubeanic acid) is typically performed on canine liver biopsies for this reason. These special stains detect the presence of copper, the distribution (periportal versus centrilobular), and can allow for a subjective assessment of the severity of any such accumulation. Assessment also entails identifying which cells are accumulating the copper (macrophages and/or hepatocytes) and whether its presence is associated with necrotic hepatocytes, and formation of small ‘copper granulomas’.

Contextual materials: Myoglobin and free hemoglobin impart a reddish color to the urine that does not clear with settling or centrifugation (Figure 8a,b). Both pigments can turn darker over time, while the sample awaits analysis, but myoglobin more consistently turns reddish-­brown to brown in color [2]. In this situation, the reagent pad will be positive for occult blood (see Chapter 5), but intact erythrocytes are not seen in the urinary sediment. In patients with hemoglobinuria, the serum will be pink owing to hemoglobin binding to haptoglobin. Myoglobin has no carrier protein, and its presence does not result in discoloration of serum because it is rapidly cleared from the circulation. A simple screening test using ammonium sulfate can discriminate between myoglobin and hemoglobin in urine. Myoglobin in urine largely stays in solution when exposed to 80% saturation of urine with ammonium sulfate, whereas hemoglobin is completely precipitated [16]. Although evaluation of serum color and use of ammonium sulfate precipitation testing can presumptively distinguish between hemoglobinuria and myoglobinuria, definitive differentiation requires urinary protein electrophoresis. Myoglobinuria probably occurs more commonly than diagnosed because it is easily confused with hemoglobinuria. Myoglobinuria sometimes is observed with exertional rhabdomyolysis in horses and dogs, and during postanesthetic rhabdomyolysis in horses [17–19]. Porphyrins in urine turn red after oxidation of porphobilinogen. This color intensifies upon standing and often is described as red or port wine [3]. The color of the urine supernatant does not change after centrifugation. In cats, porphyrinuria has been described as imparting an orange–brown color to urine that becomes orange–pink during fluorescence. Teeth of affected cats are also discolored with an orange–brown shade and undergo red fluorescence [20–23]. Intermittent porphyria and congenital erythropoietic porphyria have been described in cats [23]. Rabbits often can have red urine as a result of ingesting porphyrins in cabbage, carrots, dandelions, parsley or broccoli, and this red color can be a normal finding [24]. King George III of England (1738–1820) reportedly had urine that was blue as a consequence of hereditary intermittent porphyria [25].

question:
Contextual materials: Bird thymus originates from the third, fourth, and fifth pharyngeal pouches. The primitive cells migrate distally to form a solid mass of cells of the future thymus. They are completely separated from the pharyngeal endodermal cells. Mesenchymal cells migrate to the thymus from the surrounding head mesenchyme and arrive through the blood vessels penetrating the thymic tissue. Head mesenchymal cells form the stroma except for the epithelial-­ reticular component which is endodermal in origin. These cells produce the meshwork or the reticulum within the thymus. The thymus migrates superficially along the cervical region close to the external jugular vein and vagus nerve to reach the entrance of the thoracic portion of the celomic cavity. It is usually represented by six to eight lobes completely separated from each other (Singh 2019) (Figure 5). One should be careful when describing the thymus location from the upper cervical to the first few thoracic vertebrae because it continues to migrate caudally and distally with age. Therefore, it will be higher in the cervical region at a very young age and lower with advancing age.

C: Head mesenchymal cells enter the thymic primordium via blood vessels and form the stroma, whereas the epithelial-reticular meshwork derives from endodermal cells that were originally part of the pharyngeal pouches
D: Neural crest-derived head mesenchymal cells form both the stromal reticulum and epithelial-reticular framework after entering from surrounding mesenchyme; endodermal cells remain confined to the pharyngeal wall

question:
Contextual materials: The most common abnormal urine color is pink, red, or reddish brown and can be attributed to intact red blood cells (RBC), hemolyzed RBC, muscle pigments, food pigments, or porphyrins (Figure 3). The most common cause of pink to red urine is the presence of intact RBC (hematuria) (Figure 4.4a–e). Intact RBC in urine impart a pink to brown color to urine, depending on the number of RBC, urine pH, and length of time the RBC have been in the urine [2]. A substantial number of RBC must be present in urine before a pink or red color is observed (Figure 4.5). Light pink color was observed in urine from dogs when approximately 600 RBC/hpf were present in the urine sediment and dark pink color was observed when 800–950 RBC/hpf were present [14]. Red color from intact RBC in urine clears with centrifugation or settling (Figure 4.6). Hemoglobinuria from intravascular hemolysis or lysis of previously intact red cells in the urine specimen (in vivo or in vitro) also may cause reddish color that persists in the supernatant after settling or centrifugation (Figure 4.7a,b). Uncommonly, the presence of myoglobinuria, or rarely porphyrinuria, may cause a reddish color (see also Chapter 5, occult blood). Rarely, dyes used in the manufacture of some dry dog foods or ingestion of an unusual food item will impart a pink color to the urine. Discoloration caused by free hemoglobin, myoglobin, porphyrin, or dyes will persist in the urine supernatant after centrifugation, because they are dissolved in the urine. The term “beeturia” has been used to describe pink to deep red discolored urine from human patients after eating beets or foods that have been colored with beet pigments. Betacyanuria is the preferred scientific term that describes these red pigments in urine. Betanin and its epimer isobetanin contribute most of this red color. Urine can become progressively pinker when beetroot pigments are exposed to sunlight. High performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) can be used to definitively identify beetroot pigments in urine, but this is not clinically necessary since beeturia is a benign condition. A main concern in human medicine is that beeturia can be misdiagnosed as painless hematuria [15]. The occurrence of beeturia in urine of dogs and cats is not known.
