question:
Contextual materials: Diagnosis of feline heartworm disease remains difficult. Peripheral eosinophilia is present in \(<50\%\) of cases. Radiographic findings in feline heartworm disease are reflected by enlargement of caudal pulmonary lobar arteries to greater than 6 times the size of the ninth rib (Figure 8.5). However, in some cases pulmonary infiltrates can obscure visualization of the vasculature, and in one study of naturally infected cats, abnormalities in the pulmonary vasculature were uncommon (Venco et al. 2008). Unlike dogs, cardiac chambers are unlikely to be changed by heartworm infection. Focal or diffuse bronchointerstitial infiltrates are the most common parenchymal changes in cats with heartworm, but the presence and type of infiltrates depend on the stage of disease (Venco et al. 2008). Heartworm antibody positivity indicates only exposure to heartworm, and false-­ negative tests are unfortunately common. The antigen test can detect a single female heartworm, but can be falsely negative when no females are present or when only a few live males are present. Also, antigen–antibody complex formation appears to be more problematic in cats than in dogs, and heat-­treating serum leads to a substantial increase in positive antigen tests in infected cats (Little et al. 2014). This methodology is not advised as a screening test however, because of an increase in false-­positive results. Heartworm disease can be diagnosed on echocardiography by the presence of two parallel hyperechoic lines in the right ventricle or pulmonary artery

B: Prioritize thoracic radiography for diagnosis, because pulmonary vascular abnormalities are typically prominent and cardiac chamber enlargement is a consistent feature in cats
C: Interpret a negative antigen test cautiously—especially when infection may involve only males or no females—and reserve heat treatment for select cases rather than routine screening due to increased false-positive risk
D: Use heat-treated serum for heartworm antigen testing as the primary screening tool, because it markedly increases detection of antigen–antibody complexes without materially increasing false positives

question:
Contextual materials: So far, resistance of helminths to anthelmintics has not been found to be a problem in pigs. Treatment should be carried out in adults on a 6-monthly basis, with outdoor pigs being moved to clean pasture and indoor pigs having their accommodation steam cleaned. Growing pigs should be treated at 8 weeks of age and then every 2 months until maturity. It is important to remember to reduce the risk of resistance by treating animals up to weight. Only licensed medicines for pigs should be used. Control of helminths in pigs can be easily accomplished in commercial herds by in-feed ivermectin or fenbendazole given at 6-monthly intervals. Individual treatments can be given by i.m. injection of doramectin at 3 mg/10 kg or by s.c. injection of ivermectin at 300 μg/kg. Small group treatment may be carried out by in-water medication of flubendazole at 1 mg/kg for 5 days or fenbendazole oral pellets at 5 mg/kg as a single dose. As with all medication, meat withdrawal periods must be followed.

B: Treat adults at 8 weeks and then every 2 months until maturity; steam-clean only if clinical signs persist; administer s.c. ivermectin at 300 mg/kg; allow off-label products if they are cheaper
C: Treat adults annually; rotate among doramectin i.m. 3 mg/10 kg, ivermectin s.c. 300 μg/kg, and fenbendazole pellets 5 mg/kg single dose every month; avoid moving outdoor pigs to prevent stress-related losses

question:
Contextual materials: In all cases where there is no chance of any eye condition recovering, enucleation should be considered on welfare grounds. This can be carried out under heavy sedation, normally with xylazine. Local anaesthetic should be instilled all around the orbit, not only under the skin but also into the deeper tissues with a single very deep injection of 5 ml behind the eye to block the optic nerve. The eyelids should then be sutured together and the whole area clipped and prepared aseptically. A careful incision is then made through the skin parallel to the upper eyelid margin, but not entering the conjunctival sac. Using blunt dissection, the eye muscles are sectioned around that half of the eye. The same procedure is then carried out on the lower half. Eventually, a pair of curved scissors can be used to section the optic nerve and the eye can be removed. The remaining socket can then be obliterated with subcuticular suturing with absorbable material and the remaining eyelids sutured with non-absorbable material. The animal should receive antibiotics and NSAIDs for a minimum of 5 days. The sutures should be removed in 10 days.

question:
Contextual materials: Spring viraemia of carp (SVC) is an acute viral disease of carps and some other cyprinid and ictalurid species causing haemorrhagic and contagious viraemia [15]. It causes significant mortality during spring [16]. This disease is OIE-notifiable and is caused by SVC virus (SVCV), a member of the genus Vesiculovirus under the family Rhabdoviridae in the order Mononegavirales. The virus is enveloped and bulletshaped, measuring approximately 80–180 nm in length and 60–90 nm in diameter. The genome of the virus is non-segmented, single-stranded negative-sense RNA consisting of 11,019 nucleotides encoding five proteins: a nucleoprotein (N), a phosphoprotein (P), a matrix protein (M), a glycoprotein (G), and an RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (L). The non-virion (NV) gene found in between the G and L genes in Novirhabdovirus genus of Rhabdoviridae family is missing in this virus [16]. Based on the partial G gene sequence, SVCV isolates are classified into four genotypes, 1a, 1b, 1c, and 1d. Isolates from North America and Asia belong to genotype 1a, while isolates from Europe belong to genotypes 1b, 1c, and 1d [96].
question: A rhabdovirus isolated from sick carp has an enveloped, bullet-shaped particle and an unsegmented, negative-sense RNA genome that encodes the N, P, M, G, and L proteins. Genome sequencing shows there is no extra gene located between the G and L genes, and analysis of a partial G gene sequence groups the isolate within genotype 1c. Based on all these observations, which conclusion is most consistent?
A: It is inconsistent with SVCV because a five-protein genome implies positive-sense RNA replication; genotype 1c therefore indicates a reassortant European strain
B: It is inconsistent with SVCV because vesiculoviruses typically carry an NV gene between G and L; genotype 1c therefore indicates an Asian origin
C: It is consistent with a Novirhabdovirus because the absence of an NV gene between G and L is a defining feature of that genus, and genotype 1c is typical of North America
D: It is consistent with spring viraemia of carp virus (SVCV) and most likely represents a European lineage rather than a North American/Asian lineage

question:
Contextual materials: Entrance of air into the pleural space causes intrapleural pressure to become positive, which results in collapse of the lungs with a subsequent drop in venous return and cardiac output. Pneumothorax can be closed or open depending on whether or not there is communication between the pleural space and outside the thorax. The most common causes of pneumothorax in dogs are likely blunt force trauma from car collisions or penetrating trauma from an inhaled foreign body. Exposure to porcupine quills has also resulted in pneumothorax in the northern United States and Canada (Sevy et al. 2023). In the cat, blunt trauma occurs from a car accident or fall from a height, although inflammatory lower airway disease is also a common cause of pneumothorax (Mooney et al. 2012). In dogs or cats, esophageal perforation can lead to pneumothorax, and it can also result from rupture of an emphysematous bulla, pleural bleb, neoplasm, Paragonimus cyst, or abscessed lung lobe. Lung necrosis due to embolization associated with heartworm disease or pulmonary thromboembolic disease has also been implicated in pneumothorax. Barotrauma during anesthesia or mechanical ventilation is recognized as an iatrogenic cause of pneumothorax and it can also occur post-­thoracocentesis or fine-­needle lung aspiration. Multiple lung lobes can be involved depending on the underlying disease process, and cranial lobes are affected most commonly in spontaneous pneumothorax.
question: A dog develops a pneumothorax following positive-pressure ventilation, leading to lung collapse and a drop in cardiac output. Which sequence of pathophysiologic events most accurately accounts for the resulting hemodynamic instability?
A: Alveolar overdistension primarily decreases pulmonary vascular resistance, causing pulmonary overcirculation and a secondary fall in systemic venous return
B: Pleural air increases intrapleural pressure above atmospheric levels, compresses intrathoracic veins, reduces venous return, and thereby decreases cardiac output
C: Pleural air decreases intrapleural pressure further below atmospheric levels, increasing transmural venous pressure and causing reflex bradycardia with reduced cardiac output
D: Bronchial obstruction leads to lobar atelectasis, which increases venous return via enhanced negative intrathoracic pressure, but cardiac output falls due to reduced myocardial contractility

Contextual materials: The snake mite Ophionyssus natricis appears as red to dark-coloured pin-head mites hiding under the overlapping edges of scales, although they are also commonly found around the commissures of the mouth. question:
Contextual materials: Idiopathic Megaesophagus Idiopathic megaesophagus is the most common cause of regurgitation in the dog.10 Aside from dysautonomia, megaesophagus is a rare finding in the domestic cat. The disorder is characterized by esophageal hypomotility and dilation, progressive regurgitation, and loss of body condition. Several forms of the syndrome have been described, including congenital, acquired secondary, and acquired idiopathic megaesophagus. Dysautonomia Dysautonomia is a generalized autonomic neuropathy that was originally reported in cats in the United Kingdom, but that has now been documented in dogs and cats throughout Western Europe and the United States.11,12 Clinical signs reflect a generalized autonomic dysfunction but megaesophagus, esophageal hypomotility, and regurgitation are fairly consistent findings. Pathologically, degenerative lesions are found in autonomic ganglia, intermediate gray columns of the spinal cord, and some sympathetic axons. No definitive etiology has ever been established despite an intensive search for genetic, toxic, nutritional, and infectious etiologic agents. Gastroesophageal Intussusception Gastroesophageal intussusception is a rare condition of young dogs (most younger than 3 months of age) resulting from invagination of stomach into the esophagus, with or without other abdominal organs (e.g., spleen, duodenum, pancreas, omentum).17 Many affected animals have preexisting esophageal disease, most importantly idiopathic megaesophagus. The role of idiopathic megaesophagus in the pathogenesis of gastroesophageal intussusception is not well understood, but it may be that the greatly enlarged capacity of a dilated esophagus accommodates invagination of the stomach through the diaphragmatic hiatus. Gastroesophageal intussusception is a true gastrointestinal emergency that may culminate in death if untreated.

question:
Contextual materials: The causative organism  of bluetongue disease, Bluetongue virus (BTV), is an Orbivirus with 24 serotypes, which tend to be restricted to certain areas. Various species of Culicoides midges are required as vectors. Replication of the virus has to occur in the vector. BTV serotype 8 first came to northern Europe in 2006 and caused the birth of ‘dummy’ calves. BTV is primarily a disease of sheep and goats, but the first recorded case in the UK was in a cow. Bluetongue is a notifiable disease and a number of cases were reported in the UK in  Normally the virus is asymptomatic in cattle except for causing abortions and stillbirths with central nervous system (CNS) defects. If there are signs of clinical disease in cattle they are caused by endothelial damage and disseminated intravascular coagulation, and are shown as haemorrhage, ischaemia, inflammation and oedema. The lesions are common in areas subject to mechanical trauma and abrasion, e.g. the feet, mouth and eyes. There is fever up to 42°C. The diagnosis is confirmed by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for viral RNA. It can detect all 24 serotypes. There is no specific treatment for BTV. Antibiotics and non-steroidal anti-inflammatories (NSAIDs) are helpful. Nursing is vital and should include offering water and mushy food, and providing deep bedding out of the sun and heat. There are vaccines available which are monovalent for each serotype. Cattle require two doses separated by 2 weeks.

Contextual materials: Some reptiles will have problems shedding the skin. This is called dysecdysis. Contextual materials: ‘Mouth rot’ is the colloquial term for stomatitis, commonly seen in many reptiles particularly in snakes and chelonians. The causes are many and varied. Contextual materials: A parvovirus known as Aleutian disease is particularly lethal to mink, but in ferrets it produces unpleasant diarrhoea, although it is rarely fatal. It may produce melaenic faeces, fever, loss of weight and a number of other immune system-­mediated symptoms. Ferret epizootic coronaviral enteritis is an alphacoronavirus and results in high morbidity (up to 100%) but low mortality (<5%). \((<5\%)\) Clinical signs include lethargy and anorexia for a period of 48–72 hours after infection, with vomiting initially which then stops. After this profuse green (bile-­stained) diarrhoea with mucus is produced (so-­called ‘green slime disease’). Older ferrets with other diseases may show more severe clinical signs including intestinal ulceration. Younger ferrets have milder disease that resolves in 5–7 days. Some ferrets may be left with a maldigestion/ malabsorption syndrome. Clinical tests may show hypoalbuminaemia and increased ALT and alkaline phosphatase with a leukocytosis.
question: A veterinarian needs to differentiate between two viral gastrointestinal diseases in ferrets: parvoviral Aleutian disease and alphacoronavirus-associated ferret epizootic coronaviral enteritis (ECE). C: High morbidity approaching 100% in a group outbreak, vomiting early that ceases, followed by profuse bile-stained green mucoid diarrhoea, with hypoalbuminaemia and increased ALT/alkaline phosphatase
D: Sporadic cases with melaena, fever, weight loss and prominent immune-mediated signs, with mortality commonly exceeding 20% in ferrets

question:
Contextual materials: Pancreas disease (PD) or sleeping disease (SD) is an OIE-listed disease caused by infection with salmonid alphavirus (SAV) in Atlantic salmon, rainbow trout, common dab [21], and Arctic charr [22]. The disease is a systemic viral disease characterized by necrosis of exocrine pancreatic tissue, cardiomyocytic necrosis, and white skeletal muscle degeneration [15]. SAV is an enveloped spherical virus measuring 60–70 nm in diameter belonging to the genus Alphavirus and family Togaviridae. The genome consists of a positive-sense, single-stranded RNA of approximately 12 kb. The genome codes for eight proteins, four of which are non-structural proteins (nsP1–nsP4), and the remaining four are capsid glycoproteins (E1, E2, E3 and 6K). Glycoprotein E2 induces neutralizing antibodies [21] and, hence, is an ideal candidate for developing sub-unit or DNA vaccines. Based on the sequences of protein E2 and nsP3, SAV isolates have been divided into six genotypes, SAV1–SAV6 [134]. Gills and intestinal track are the portals of entry. Although the predilection sites of the virus are not known, in acute cases, high titre of the virus is found in kidney, heart, blood, and several other organs. Virus is shed through mucus and faeces. Disease outbreaks are influenced by environmental factors, and increase in water temperature favours the virus [135]. The disease affects all life-stages in both freshwater and seawater [136]. The virus persists in the infected fish for several months and is transmitted horizontally through water [137].
question: Which characteristic most strongly justifies choosing a particular SAV structural protein as the main antigen for sub-unit or DNA vaccine design, instead of focusing on non-structural proteins or other envelope proteins?
A: E1 is essential for virion assembly in enveloped Alphavirus particles, implying it is the most immunodominant determinant of neutralization
B: E2 is a capsid glycoprotein that induces neutralizing antibodies, making it a principal target for protective humoral immunity
C: nsP3 sequence variation is used to define SAV1–SAV6 genotypes, indicating it is the dominant surface-exposed antigen under immune selection
D: 6K is encoded by the 12 kb positive-sense RNA genome and is therefore the most conserved protein, maximizing cross-genotype vaccine coverage

question:
Contextual materials: Blood collection can be particularly challenging in amphibians. Alcohol should not be used to clean the venipuncture site. This can irritate and/or desiccate the patient’s skin. A 1:40 diluted 2% chlorhexidine solution should be used to cleanse the site instead. Venipuncture in salamanders is generally performed using the caudal tail vein. This is the same technique described previously for both lizards and snakes. It is important to remember that the vessel is very small and can collapse easily; therefore, do not place a large amount of negative pressure on the syringe during collection. A 25- to 27-gauge needle attached to a 1-mL syringe should be used. An insulin syringe can also be used for very small patients. The blood sample should be placed in a heparinized Microtainer tube for analysis. Venipuncture sites in frogs and toads include the femoral vein, ventral abdominal vein, and the lingual vein. The femoral and lingual veins are rarely used. The ventral abdominal vein is by far the easiest vessel to obtain a blood sample from. The frog or toad is gently positioned on its back with the restrainer holding the pectoral girdle. The person drawing blood can hold the pelvic girdle with one hand and draw blood with the other hand. Restraint without gloves can damage the epithelium and cause subsequent elevated white blood cell counts. Some amphibians will need to be anesthetized for venipuncture. This can be achieved with a 2%–3% MS222 solution. A 1-mL syringe with a 25- to 27-gauge needle is generally used to obtain the sample although an insulin syringe can be used as well. The blood sample should be placed into a heparinized Microtainer tube for analysis. Blood volume needs to be considered in these small patients. No more than 1% of the body weight should be taken in blood volume from healthy amphibians, and no more than 5% should be taken from sick patients.

question:
Contextual materials: Tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated factor (TRAF) family members (TRAF1-7) are intracellular signal transducers involved in inflammation and include immune receptor superfamilies, such as the tumor necrosis factor receptor (TNFR) superfamily and interleukin-1 receptor/Toll-like receptor (IL-1/TLR) family members (Inoue et al., 2000). All TRAFs have a similar protein structure, an N-terminal region, and C-terminal TRAF domain (Rothe et al., 1994). The N-terminal contains a RING-finger domain and a series of five Zn-finger domains, which mediate protein ubiquitylation and activation of downstream signaling (Yang et al., 2015). The TRAF domain is comprised of a coiled-coil TRAF-N domain and a conserved TRAF-C domain, which is involved in self-association (Rothe et al., 1994) and interaction with various upstream regulators or downstream effectors (Zheng et al., 2010). TRAF6 was originally isolated by yeast two-hybrid screening using CD40 as bait (Ishida et al., 1996), and independently by screening of an expressed sequence tag (EST) library (Cao et al., 1996), and has been identified as a critical element for IL-1/TLR signaling. TRAF6 is the only TRAF family member that participates in both TNFR superfamily signaling pathways and TLR/IL-1R superfamily pathways (Chung et al., 2002).
question: Which member of the TRAF family is uniquely involved as a signaling adaptor in both TNFR superfamily signaling and TLR/IL-1R superfamily signaling pathways?

D: TRAF1

Contextual materials: FOXO3 is involved in many biological processes where it functions as a transcriptional regulator. The functions of FOXO3 in the control of the cell cycle may explain its association with longevity. FOXO3 induces cellular apoptosis by activating apoptosis-related factors, such as Fas ligand  $(FasL)$ , BCL2 interacting protein 3 (BNIP3), autophagy-related 8 (ATG8), TNF superfamily member 10 (TRAIL), and phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) (Nakamura et al., 2000; Ghaffari et al., 2003; Shao et al., 2016). FOXO3 is an activator of the protein degradation pathway and it can promote the expression of muscle atrophy factors, including F-box protein 32 (FBXO32) (also known as atrogin 1) and muscle specific ring finger protein (MURF) to induce the atrophy of muscles (Lee et al., 2004; Sandri et al., 2004). In addition, the downstream genes of FOXO3 include microtubule-associated protein 1 light chain 3 (LC3), ubiquitin-binding protein  $p62$ , and Neighbor of BRCA1 gene 1 protein (NBR1), which are all involved in the muscle atrophy process (Mammucari et al., 2007). Thus, the inhibition of FOXO3 expression lead to the suppression of protein degradation as well as increasing the thickness of muscle fibers and the body weight (Zhao et al., 2007a).

question:
Contextual materials: Chicken type I interferons (type I IFNs) are key antiviral players of chicken immune system and mediate the first line of defense against viral pathogens infecting the avian species. Chicken type I IFNs are activated by various host cell pathways and constitute major antiviral innate defense in chicken.

C: Constitutive expression of IFN-stimulated antiviral proteins → PRR upregulation → chIFN-κ receptor engagement → suppression of chIFN-α/β → antiviral state via reduced interferon signaling

Contextual materials: Bacteria of the genus Salmonella can infect humans and animals. Two of the main pathogens of these genera infecting animals, and specifically poultry, are Salmonella enterica serovar Pollurum (S. Pullorum) and Salmonella enterica serovar Gallinarum (S. Gallinarum) [1]. Their economic impact in terms of loss in the poultry sector is due to their killing effect after infection. Both strains can cause death in up to $90\%$ of birds affected [1,2]. Another example is Salmonella enterica serovar Enteritidis (S. Enteritidis), which can infect humans through consumption of contaminated meat and eggs. At the same time, poultry infected with S. Enteritidis infect their healthy neighbors contributing to further economic loss. S. Enteritidis is one of the main foodborne pathogens responsible for spreading Salmonella in humans, representing a public health issue [3,4]. The indiscriminate use of antibiotics as growth promoters for weight gain in poultry contributed to the spread of antibiotic-resistant microorganisms in humans and has prompted the prohibition of antibiotics in the poultry sector, so bacteriophages or phages (viruses that infect and lyse bacteria) have emerged as a strategy bio-control of Salmonella. This can include applications intended to limit the spread of the bacterium or directly for the treatment of salmonellosis in poultry, an approach known as phage therapy [5-12].
question: Which situation most clearly justifies switching from antibiotic growth promoters to bacteriophage-based measures in poultry farming, while also tackling a related public health issue in humans?
A: Eliminating Salmonella foodborne disease in humans by banning poultry products, making phage therapy unnecessary for animal health management
B: Reducing mortality from S. Pullorum and S. Gallinarum by using phages solely to increase bird weight gain, thereby lowering the risk of viral zoonoses in humans
C: Preventing S. Enteritidis from infecting poultry by vaccinating humans, which removes selective pressure for antibiotic resistance in agricultural settings
D: Curbing the emergence of antibiotic-resistant microorganisms linked to indiscriminate antibiotic use in poultry by deploying phages to control Salmonella, including limiting transmission of S. Enteritidis that contaminates meat and eggs consumed by humans

question:
Contextual materials: Although all NDV isolates belong to a single serotype, the viruses are genetically and antigenically diverse. Based on genetic differences, NDV are currently classified in two major groups (class I and class II) (Czegledi et al., 2006), and the class II viruses have higher genetic and virulence variability and are known to infect a wide range of domestic and wild birds. They are divided into at least 18 genotypes (named I to XVIII), and vNDV belonging to multiple class II genotypes are identified in poultry outbreaks worldwide (Dimitrov et al., 2016). vNDV from different genotypes are often identified in wild birds, and the latter have been speculated to play a role in the spread of the virus (Snoeck et al., 2013). However, it is suggested that most of the wild bird isolations are a result of spillover of virus from infected poultry (Miller and Koch, 2013). Notably, there are two known exceptions where virulent viruses are endemic in wild birds. Birds of the family Columbidae are known to be a reservoir of the antigenic variants of vNDV, commonly referred to as pigeon paramyxoviruses 1 (PPMV-1). These pigeon-origin viruses are distributed worldwide, are commonly isolated from both wild and domestic pigeons, and are highly virulent for these species (Ujvari et al., 2003). The second group of viruses are endemic in some species of the genus Phalacrocorax (cormorant populations) in North America and are associated with periodic mortality events (Banerjee et al., 1994). Both groups of viruses have the potential to infect other avian species but appear to be highly adapted to pigeons and cormorants, respectively, and are rarely implicated with infections in poultry.
question: Which option best describes the ecology and classification of virulent Newcastle disease virus (vNDV), clearly differentiating viruses that are truly endemic in wild birds from those typically resulting from spillover from infected poultry?

B: NDV is divided into class I and class II solely by antigenic variation; class II is genetically stable with a single dominant genotype, and wild birds maintain most poultry outbreaks through endemic infection.
C: NDV is a single serotype but genetically diverse; class II contains greater genetic and virulence variability and includes multiple genotypes, while most wild-bird detections are spillover from poultry except for endemic virulent lineages in Columbidae (PPMV-1) and some North American Phalacrocorax species.
D: Despite comprising multiple serotypes, NDV shows limited genetic diversity; most virulent strains are class I, with wild birds serving as primary endemic reservoirs across genotypes.

question:
Contextual materials: The chicken genome is one-third the size of the human genome and has a similarity of sixty percent when it comes to gene content. question:
Contextual materials: Endotoxin or lipopolysaccharide (LPS) is found in the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria. Few studies have been performed to assess the effects of endotoxin exposure on immunity of livestock. LPS administration through intravenous injection into 7- to 8-month old chickens was reported to rapidly reduce the number of monocytes in peripheral blood and macrophages in the spleen; these values returned to control levels at 6 to  $24\mathrm{h}$  post-LPS injection [2]. In addition, 8-week old chickens intravenously injected with LPS had lower antibody titers following infectious bronchitis virus vaccination compared to the control group [20]. Up-regulated expression of pro-inflammatory cytokine genes such as interleukin (IL)-1 $\beta$ s, IL-6, and IL-8 was also observed in chicken heterophils in the presence of LPS in vitro [11]. Aside from these studies, few systemic investigations have been performed on the modulation of chicken immunity through endotoxin exposure via the indoor environment of chicken farms.
question: After intravenous injection of lipopolysaccharide (LPS) in 7–8-month-old chickens, what time pattern best matches the reported drop and subsequent return to baseline of innate immune cell numbers?
A: A rapid decrease in peripheral blood monocytes and splenic macrophages, with return to control levels within 6–24 hours
B: An immediate increase in both peripheral blood monocytes and splenic macrophages, followed by normalization by 6–24 hours
C: No measurable change in peripheral blood monocytes, but a rapid decrease in splenic macrophages that normalizes only after 7 days
D: A delayed decrease peaking at 48–72 hours in peripheral blood monocytes only, with persistent splenic macrophage depletion beyond one week

Contextual materials: A series of studies in vitro and in vivo demonstrated that $\mathrm{Cr(VI)}$ can induce oxidative stress by enhancing the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS). C: Cr(VI) generates only hydrogen peroxide via Cr(IV) intermediates; neuronal membranes resist peroxidation due to low polyunsaturated fatty acids, so injury is chiefly due to protein crosslinking rather than oxidative stress

Contextual materials: The IFITM3 protein is localized in the late endosome to prevent viral invasion (Feeley et al. 2011). Although mammals and birds share a very similar protein structure called CD225, which is significantly associated with antiviral ability, birds do not likely depend on the YxxΦ domain for correct IFITM3 protein localization.

question:
Contextual materials: Noroviruses (NoV) are members of the Caliciviridae family, and are important pathogens that cause gastroenteritis in children and young animals (Karst and Tibbetts, 2016; Villabruna et al., 2019). Four distinct genotypes (GIV.2, GVI.1, GVI.2 and GVII) have been previously identified in canine norovirus(CNV) (Scipioni et al., 2008; Villabruna et al., 2019). Extensive epidemiological data suggest that CNV is a diarrhea-causing pathogen of canine, however, with no suitable cell culture system for CNV, the precise pathogenicity of CNV has not been investigated. Currently, CNV strains have been detected in at least eight countries with a wide geographical distribution, GIV.2 strains have been detected in six countries (Martella et al., 2008; Ntafis et al., 2010; Lyoo et al., 2018; Soma et al., 2015; Mesquita and Nascimento, 2012b), GVI.1 strains have been detected in four countries (Mesquita et al., 2010; Martella et al., 2009; Ford-Siltz et al., 2019), GVI.2 strains have been detected in five countries (Bodnar et al., 2017; Mesquita and Nascimento, 2012a; Mihalov-Kovács et al., 2014), and GVII strains have only been detected in Hong Kong, China (Tse et al., 2012).

question:
Contextual materials: Canine theileriosis is a notorious tick borne piroplasmid infection of wild and domestic canines. The causative agent has not yet been accurately classified. PCR studies revealed that causative agent resembles to Theileria genus and thus provisionally named as Theileria annae. The other Theileria species reported in canines is Theileria annulata, Theileria equi and unnamed Theileria specie. This emergent canine infection is considered to be endemic in most of the European countries. However in Asia this disease has not been reported till date. The vectors responsible for transmission of this disease have not been determined. It has been suggested that DNA of Theileria annae has been detected in hard tick Ixodes hexagonus in Northwestern Spain and several other tick species. Clinically canine theileriosis is characterized by severe weakness, fever, hemoglobinuria and anemia. Recently atovaquone or buparvaquone plus azithromycin therapy showed better clinical efficacy. This comprehensive review is intended to summarize the current knowledge on prevalence and epidemiology of canine theileriosis in different countries of the world and associated tick vectors.

question:
Contextual materials: CMTs have heterogeneous morphology and biology which makes it difficult to choose the most appropriate biomarker for its diagnosis. The tumors are usually noticed by owners when there are visible macroscopic changes in the mammary gland. Determination of tumor biomarker for CMT can be a milestone for early diagnosis of the disease in dogs which can help evaluate the progress of the disease and its response to chemotherapy (Kaszak et al. 2018). B: Rely primarily on gross mammary gland changes reported by owners, since heterogeneous morphology makes serum biomarkers unreliable for screening
C: Prefer CA 15-3 alone over CEA because both markers have been used for more than 30 years and redundancy reduces clinical value
D: Measure postoperative CEA only, since recurrence monitoring is the sole clinically validated role of serum tumor markers

question:
Contextual materials: The function of specific traits has often been inferred from the magnitude of the scaling exponent of a power function, b [12]. In particular, sexually selected ornaments and weapons frequently show positive allometry with body size dimensions  $(b > 1$  for comparisons between measures with the same dimensions, e.g. length-length), due to differential resource allocation to structures that enhance mating success. Slopes as high as 3.4, with a mode between 1.5-2.0, occur in traits associated with sexual display (e.g. antler size in the giant deer Megaloceros), possibly for reasons such as the "handicap principle" [12,13,19,20] whereby traits that are supposedly disadvantageous, and therefore costly to maintain, advertise for 'better' quality of individuals that can maintain them. On the other hand, traits that have evolved under natural rather than sexual selection often scale isometrically against body size (i.e. geometric similarity, slope=1), but in some cases can also show positive or negative allometries [12,13,20,21].
question: A scientist compares the length of a sexually selected weapon to body length across multiple individuals and finds a scaling exponent of about **b = 3.2**. Which explanation best matches this strongly positive allometry and the evolutionary reasoning commonly used to account for it?
A: Negative allometry indicating diminishing investment in the trait with increasing size, suggesting stabilizing natural selection against conspicuousness
B: Strong positive allometry typical of sexually selected traits, plausibly aligning with handicap-principle logic that costly exaggeration signals individual quality
C: Isometric scaling consistent with geometric similarity, implying primarily natural selection for locomotor efficiency
D: A dimension-mismatch artifact that cannot be interpreted for length–length comparisons, implying the exponent is biologically meaningless

Contextual materials: Canine medical scent detection appears more promising for infectious diseases than non-infectious diseases such as cancer, diabetes mellitus and epileptic seizures. question:
Contextual materials: The regenerative capability of the mammalian spinal cord is very limited [12]. Complete regeneration would require production of new neurons and glia with successful reinnervation of the correct targets in order to restore function. There is still no therapy tailored to this complex scenario. The discovery of resident stem cells within the nervous system has created the promise of new therapies [13]. Strategically, stem cells can advance current techniques based on combined points of action: activation of resident neural stem cells from their dormant state, their differentiation into relevant cell types (neurons, glial cells), regulation of scar formation, prevention of cyst formation, and secretion of neurotrophic and other factors to promote matrix repair and regeneration [14, 15]. For example, mesenchymal stromal cells and neural crest stem cells modulate oxidative stress, and secrete cytokines and growth factors that have immunomodulatory, anti-inflammatory, pro-angiogenic and anti-apoptotic effects [16, 17]. Extensive research has been done using cell transplantation for SCI, however most of the candidates do not translate to clinical utility [9, 18].

B: Reduction of oxidative stress coupled with secretion of cytokines and growth factors producing immunomodulatory, anti-inflammatory, pro-angiogenic, and anti-apoptotic effects
C: Exclusive promotion of astrocytic differentiation to accelerate dense scar formation and intentional induction of cystic cavitation to guide axonal regrowth
D: Primary enhancement of myelination through enforced oligodendrocyte hyperplasia while blocking cytokine release to avoid immune-system interference

question:
Contextual materials: D. immitis is one of several species of parasitic nematode that house the obligate symbiont bacteria Wolbachia pipientis (Bandi et al. 2001). Large colonies of Wolbachia reside in the subdermal lateral cords of both male and female nematodes, as well as in the reproductive structures of females (Slatko et al. 2010). Within the past decade, scientists demonstrated the obligate nature of this symbiosis by treating pathogenic nematodes with antibiotics, which quickly curtailed embryogenesis, progression of larval stages, and growth of adult worms (Slatko et al. 2010). It is now widely accepted by those within the field of heartworm research that the presence of W. pipientis within the bodies of adult worms is vital to survival and reproduction. Evidence towards the intense coevolution of this symbiosis can be found in the phylogenetic connections among many worms that contain Wolbachia, as well as the existence of Wolbachia within the common bedbug, among other insect species (Bandi et al. 2001; Slatko et al. 2010). The fact that Wolbachia surface protein (WSP) illicits a damaging humoral response from canine tissue in D. immitis infections suggests that D. immitis selection for storage of Wolbachia combats the typical parasite attenuation strategy within the host. Therefore, current studies aim to develop treatment implementing both antibiotics and macrocyclic lactones (Ivermectin).
question: In Dirofilaria immitis infections, which proposed mechanism most effectively explains both the swift reduction in embryogenesis following antibiotic therapy and the finding that Wolbachia surface protein (WSP) triggers a harmful humoral immune response in canine tissues?

B: Wolbachia is an obligate mutualist required for normal worm development and reproduction, and despite WSP-driven host damage, retaining Wolbachia is selectively favored because it counteracts typical within-host parasite attenuation
C: Antibiotics directly disrupt nematode mitochondrial translation, and WSP-induced pathology is unrelated to Wolbachia persistence within adult worms
D: Wolbachia is facultative in adults but obligate in larvae; antibiotics block larval progression without affecting adult reproductive structures where Wolbachia is absent

question:
Contextual materials: Aging canine subjects exhibit similar naturally occurring neuropathology to aging humans, such as the development of beta-amyloid plaques (Aβ) and tauopathy unlike other commonly used translational models such as mice and rats (Cummings et al., 1996, 1993; Head, 2013; Mazzatenta et al., 2017). Canine models also provide a useful evolutionary intermediate model to that of rodents featuring a gyrencephalic brain and convergent sociocognitive skills with humans (Berns et al., 2012; Thompkins et al., 2016). Though research into differences in longevity among canines is still ongoing, selective breeding and diverse features within the canine population have potential for classifying specific neuropathology phenotypes (Kaeberlein et al., 2016; Urfer et al., 2019). In addition, studies have found the aging canine brain exhibits cortical atrophy (Tapp et al., 2006), accumulates beta-amyloid with age (Kumar et al., 2018), and can develop progressive cognitive decline with memory dysfunctions as seen in Alzheimer's disease (Prpar Mihevc and Majdic, 2019). question:
Contextual materials: Canine atopic dermatitis is a complex disease that is often treated by multiple therapies either at the same time or over time. Most studies regarding efficacy are based on evaluating these drugs as sole therapy. Monotherapy is not frequently used in clinical practice because combination therapy is often necessary or more beneficial. The most common therapeutic interventions for CAD include the following: glucocorticoids, ciclosporin, antihistamines, essential fatty acids (EFAs) and allergen-specific immunotherapy (ASIT). Historically, glucocorticoids have been the most commonly prescribed medication for treatment of CAD, but even these are often used in conjunction with other therapies, such as bathing, antihistamines and fatty acids. Antihistamines have been described as having little benefit in managing atopic dermatitis;[3-5] however, antihistamines remain one of the most frequently used medications to treat the pruritus associated with CAD in dogs. Essential fatty acids, being commonly available and relatively inexpensive, are also frequently used in combination with other therapies. The slow onset of improvement with ASIT in dogs frequently results in the concurrent use of other therapies, at least during the first few months of therapy. Intermittent antimicrobial therapy is often necessary to eliminate complicating secondary infections. The most recent recommendation of the International Task Force on Canine Atopic Dermatitis focuses on this concept of a multimodal treatment approach.[4] A multimodal treatment approach will provide increased benefit to the dog by intervening at several different points along the pathway from exposure to an offending antigen to development of clinical signs (pruritus, superficial pyoderma and otitis externa).

question:
Contextual materials: Canine parvovirus type 2 (CPV-2) is a non-enveloped, single-stranded DNA virus that causes fatal gastroenteritis in young dogs<sup>1</sup>. The CPV-2 genome is 5323 nucleotide long and possesses at least 2 major open reading frames (ORFs)<sup>2</sup>. CPV-2 infections are associated with significant morbidity and mortality which can reach  $91\%$  in untreated pups<sup>3</sup>. Three variants of CPV type 2 are known, CPV-2a, CPV-2b, and CPV-2c, and are highly contagious due to suspected low infective dose requirements combined with high titers of transmissible virus in stools of affected dogs<sup>4,5</sup>. The virus is highly resistant to environmental conditions and can remain viable outside of its host for at least a year<sup>6</sup>.
question: A shelter is experiencing repeated outbreaks of deadly gastroenteritis in unvaccinated puppies, with illness and death rates nearing 91%. question:
Contextual materials: Biomechanical cervical spine models have been used extensively to evaluate feasibility and potential side effects of surgical procedures and instrumentation as it is currently not feasible to directly measure spinal loading in-vivo (Jaeger et al., 2011). Theoretical and numerical biomechanical models of the human cervical spine have been developed over the last three decades to investigate kinetics and kinematics of the neck (Dugailly et al., 2011). However, these models have not been translated to the canine cervical spine in spite of the high incidence of spinal disorders and injuries (Jeffery et al., 2013). Successful development and implementation of these models in canine spinal studies would require accurate anatomical data of the underlying soft tissues and bone (Sharir et al., 2006). Among the many components which should be incorporated into a model, muscles play a vital role in stability, loading and locomotion as they exert the majority of the required moments to maintain equilibrium in different postures and to perform various tasks (Nussbaum et al., 1995; Vasavada et al., 1998). Studies have shown the substantial effect of muscle forces on cervical spine kinematics and injury potential on the neck structure (Borst et al., 2011). To this extent, comprehensive knowledge of canine muscle properties including estimation of muscle forces and orientation has yet to be established.
question: When creating a biomechanical model of the canine cervical spine to assess surgical feasibility in situations where in-vivo spinal loads cannot be measured directly, which missing or inaccurate modeling component would most strongly compromise predictions of posture-dependent cervical stability by distorting the main generator of equilibrium moments?
A: Relying on accurate bony anatomy but simplifying soft tissues, because vertebral geometry dominates loading paths independent of posture
B: Using human cervical spine kinetics/kinematics models without adaptation, because intervertebral disc hydration differs between species
C: Focusing on instrumentation stiffness while neglecting passive ligament properties, because ligaments generate the majority of stabilizing moments during locomotion
D: Omitting detailed muscle force estimation and orientation, because muscles provide most of the moments required to maintain equilibrium

question:
Contextual materials: Staphylococcus pseudintermedius is a commensal bacterium colonizing dog skin and mucosal sites<sup>1</sup>, and it is the predominant cause of canine pyoderma and otitis externa<sup>2</sup>. These common infections represent the main reason for antimicrobial prescription in dogs<sup>3</sup>. Over the last decade, methicillin-resistant S. pseudintermedius (MRSP) has been reported worldwide<sup>4</sup>, including sporadic infections in humans in contact with dogs<sup>5,6</sup>. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is another pathogen frequently involved in canine integumentary infections, in particular otitis externa<sup>7</sup>. P. aeruginosa is resistant to most antibiotics used in veterinary medicine. The presence of this pathogen and the increasing frequency of multidrug-resistant MRSP<sup>8</sup>, make treatment of dogs with integumentary infections difficult or even impossible in some cases<sup>9</sup>. In light of the few treatment options available against these pathogens, new therapeutic agents are needed, preferably drugs restricted to veterinary use and with a narrow spectrum<sup>10</sup>. This would limit their impact on the commensal microbiota<sup>11</sup>.
question: When developing a new antimicrobial treatment for canine otitis externa and pyoderma, which option most effectively meets both requirements of preserving the commensal microbiota while still targeting pathogens such as methicillin-resistant *Staphylococcus pseudintermedius* and another organism that is naturally resistant to most antibiotics used in veterinary practice?
A: A topical antiseptic regimen as a complete substitute for antimicrobials, since intrinsic antibiotic resistance implies antibiotics are categorically ineffective
B: A veterinary-restricted, narrow-spectrum drug targeted to the relevant canine integumentary pathogens to preserve commensal microbiota while improving treatability of multidrug-resistant infections
C: A human-use systemic antibiotic reserved for last-resort therapy, deployed off-label in dogs to minimize resistance selection in veterinary settings
D: A broad-spectrum agent optimized for high tissue penetration to ensure coverage of both pathogens, accepting commensal disruption as a trade-off for efficacy

question:
Contextual materials: Core temperature is considered the gold standard of body temperature, as it closely reflects the temperature of the internal organs (Allegaert et al., 2014). The temperature at the hypothalamus is also a desired location to monitor, as this region is where body temperature is perceived (Cichocki et al., 2017). However, clinically, the most conventional method of taking a canine's temperature is through the rectal mucosa, as it continues to be a minimally invasive method that provides insight to core temperature (Kreissl and Neiger, 2015). Rectal thermometers have drawbacks, as they cannot be easily used on aggressive canids or ones with an infection or rupture of the anal mucosa (Kreissl and Neiger, 2015). To bypass the limitations caused by rectal temperatures, studies have been done using non - contact infrared (IR) thermometers, and focusing on alternative areas such as the axilla, auricular canal, and ocular regions of the canine (Gomart et al., 2014, Zanghi, 2016).
question: A veterinarian needs to obtain a dog’s temperature in a way that closely represents internal organ (core) temperature but cannot use a rectal thermometer because of anal mucosal infection and potential aggression. Which option best explains the clinical compromise involved and why non-contact infrared thermometers at other anatomical locations may be considered?
A: Rectal temperature directly measures hypothalamic temperature and is therefore preferred; infrared methods are mainly explored to improve invasiveness rather than feasibility
B: Hypothalamic temperature is the gold standard because it reflects peripheral tissues; rectal measurements are used only when infrared devices are unavailable for axillary readings
C: Core temperature is the gold standard for internal organs, but rectal thermometry is used clinically as a minimally invasive proxy with handling and mucosal-integrity limitations, motivating exploration of non-contact infrared readings at sites such as the axilla, ear canal, or ocular region
D: Rectal thermometry is avoided primarily because it systematically underestimates core temperature, whereas infrared thermometry at the ocular surface directly measures core temperature without site-dependent variability

question:
Contextual materials: Mitral valve competence requires complex interplay between structures that comprise the mitral apparatus – the mitral annulus, mitral valve leaflets, chordae tendineae, papillary muscles, and left atrial and left ventricular myocardium. Myxomatous mitral valve degeneration is prevalent in the canine, and most adult dogs develop some degree of mitral valve disease as they age, highlighting the apparent vulnerability of canine heart valves to injury. Myxomatous valvular remodeling is associated with characteristic histopathologic features. Changes include expansion of extracellular matrix with glycosaminoglycans and proteoglycans; valvular interstitial cell alteration; and attenuation or loss of the collagen-laden fibrosa layer. These lead to malformation of the mitral apparatus, biomechanical dysfunction, and mitral incompetence. Mitral regurgitation is the most common manifestation of myxomatous valve disease and in advanced stages, associated volume overload promotes progressive valvular regurgitation, left atrial and left ventricular remodeling, atrial tears, chordal rupture, and congestive heart failure. Future studies are necessary to identify clinical-pathologic correlates that track disease severity and progression, detect valve dysfunction, and facilitate risk stratification. It remains unresolved whether, or to what extent, the pathobiology of myxomatous mitral valve degeneration is the same between breeds of dogs, between canines and humans, and how these features are related to aging and genetics.
question: Which stepwise pathogenic process most convincingly connects myxomatous degeneration of the canine mitral valve to progressively worsening mitral regurgitation and the resulting remodeling of the heart?
A: Primary papillary muscle necrosis → acute annular dilation without extracellular matrix expansion → regurgitation that reduces chamber volumes over time → reverse remodeling with decreased risk of chordal rupture
B: Extracellular matrix contraction with loss of glycosaminoglycans → leaflet shortening and stenosis as the dominant lesion → pressure overload producing concentric hypertrophy and reduced likelihood of atrial tears
C: Initial thickening of the collagen-laden fibrosa layer with decreased proteoglycans → improved leaflet stiffness and competence → regurgitation only if myocarditis develops → isolated left ventricular remodeling without left atrial involvement
D: Proteoglycan/glycosaminoglycan accumulation with valvular interstitial cell alteration and fibrosa collagen attenuation → mitral apparatus malformation and biomechanical dysfunction → mitral incompetence/regurgitation → volume overload driving progressive regurgitation, atrial/ventricular remodeling, and potential chordal rupture/congestive heart failure

question:
Contextual materials: The insulin-like growth factor receptor type 2 (IGF2R) sequesters the insulin-like growth factor (IGF-II) for internalization and degradation and also is considered a tumor suppressor with mutations being found in several cancers [23]. Unusually high levels of circulating IGF-II and simultaneous downregulation of IGF2R are correlated with the growth of human and murine tumors [24,25] while loss of function of IGF2R resulting in increased growth [26]. A recent publication has shown the consistent surface overexpression of IGF2R in human OS [27]. It was also previously found that a single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) which alters methylation in an IGF2R CpG island was associated with an increased risk of OS development in humans [28]. Taken together, IGF2R expression appears to be both essential to and associated with the development of OS, making it an ideal therapeutic target. Sequence alignment of the IGFII binding region (Domains 11-FNII) in human, mouse, and dog have been demonstrated to be highly conserved (82% sequence identity) across these species [29].

A: Target IGF2R because IGF-II levels are typically low in tumors and increasing IGF2R expression would amplify mitogenic IGF-II signaling; conservation of Domains 11–FNII implies conserved growth-stimulatory signaling
B: Target IGF2R because its downregulation decreases tumor growth by limiting IGF-II internalization, and the species conservation indicates that reduced receptor function will be similarly protective across models
C: Target IGF2R because it is consistently surface-overexpressed in human osteosarcoma and its IGF-II binding region (Domains 11–FNII) is highly conserved (~82% identity) across human, mouse, and dog, enabling cross-species targeting of IGF-II sequestration
D: Target IGF2R because the osteosarcoma-associated CpG-island SNP directly increases receptor surface expression via hypomethylation, and conservation of the binding region ensures antibody specificity only in human and not in mouse or dog

question:
Contextual materials: Aged dogs are considered the most suitable spontaneous animal model for studying normal aging and neurodegenerative diseases. Elderly canines naturally develop cognitive dysfunction and neuropathological hallmarks similar to those seen in humans, especially Alzheimer's disease-like pathology. Oxidative damage accumulates in the canine brain during aging, making dogs a valid model for translational antioxidant treatment/prevention studies. Evidence suggests the presence of detective protein quality control systems, involving ubiquitin-proteasome system (UPS) and Heat Shock Proteins (HSPs), in the aged canine brain. Further studies on the canine model are needed to clarify the role of age-related changes in UPS activity and HSP expression in neurodegeneration in order to design novel treatment strategies, such as HSP-based therapies, aimed at improving chaperone defences against proteotoxic stress affecting brain during aging.
question: Which option best explains why senior pet dogs are considered a particularly robust translational model for evaluating antioxidant therapies and proteostasis-focused treatments relevant to Alzheimer’s disease–like neurodegenerative changes?
A: They are uniquely protected from oxidative damage during aging, making any observed neurodegeneration primarily attributable to infectious causes rather than proteotoxic stress
B: They reliably develop induced amyloid pathology only under laboratory diets, allowing strict control of oxidative injury while minimizing confounds from natural environments

Contextual materials: Dirofilariasis is mainly caused by the parasitic nematodes Dirofilaria immitis and Dirofilaria repens, which are transmitted by different species of culicid mosquitoes (Culex spp., Aedes spp., Anopheles spp.), the vectors that allow these nematodes to complete their life cycles [20]. question:
Contextual materials: The respiratory tract is in close and continuous contact with the outer environment. Through the gaseous exchange, myriads of airborne pathogens directly get in touch with the respiratory epithelium [1]. To prevent these organisms from causing insults, the respiratory epithelium provides a physicochemical barrier and builds, together with the innate immune system, the first line of defense [2]. In order to study host-pathogen interactions in the respiratory tract, it is essential to gain comprehensive knowledge about the characteristic cellular structure and the complexity of the respiratory tract epithelium. The latter consists of a diverse range of cell types, including basal cells, ciliated cells, brush cells, goblet cells, club cells, neuroendocrine cells, ionocytes and Hillock cells, which vary in concentration throughout the respiratory tract and form a pseudostratified, columnar epithelium [3-5]. Tight junctions are intercellular, junctional complexes expressed on the apical side of epithelial cells to maintain the integrity of the airway epithelium, which is necessary for an impermeable barrier function [6]. This physical barrier is enhanced by the mucociliary escalator, which clears the conducting airways by entrapping inhaled particles in mucus derived from secretory cells and propelling the mucus by coordinated ciliary movement anteriorly towards the pharynx [7]. In response to epithelial injury, a subset of basal cells demonstrates the capability of self-renewal and differentiation into ciliated and secretory cells for orderly regeneration and preservation of the protective barrier [8].
question: Which combination most correctly matches a characteristic of the airway epithelium with its main role in first-line defense while maintaining the epithelium’s integrity?
A: Tight junctions on the apical side of epithelial cells—maintain an impermeable barrier by sealing intercellular spaces
B: Pseudostratified columnar organization—prevents pathogen entry chiefly by functioning as the origin of replication for immune mediators
C: Basal cell self-renewal—directly propels mucus anteriorly toward the pharynx via coordinated beating
D: Mucociliary escalator—creates an impermeable barrier by forming apical junctional complexes

question:
Contextual materials: Babesia rossi, a common parasite in wild jackals, is known to cause the most severe disease of all the Babesia species infecting canines [10], and is a leading cause of infectious morbidity and mortality among the susceptible domestic dog population in South Africa [11]. question:
Contextual materials: Histotripsy, an experimental noninvasive extracorporeal focused ultrasound technology, has been explored as a less invasive approach to surgical management of BPH, demonstrating the ability to homogenize prostate tissue in an in vivo canine model with resultant tissue debulking. Histotripsy involves delivery of high amplitude, short (<50 μs) pulses of ultrasound energy at a low duty cycle (<1%) to a cigar shaped geometric focal volume. The resulting compression and rarefaction causes the development of microbubbles that oscillate, coalesce, and collapse producing mechanical fractionation of targeted tissues at the cellular level, reducing tissue architecture and cellular structures to a fine slurry of acellular debris. Volumetric ablation is accomplished by passing the transducer focal volume through the targeted region. As targeted tissue is homogenized, the US appearance becomes progressively hypoechoic. Transabdominal histotripsy of the prostate is safe and effective in an in vivo canine benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH) model producing dose dependent tissue debulking of the adenomatous BPH tissue with minimal hematuria, even in an anticoagulated model.

Contextual materials: Transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs) or prion diseases are fatal neurodegenerative disorders affecting animals and humans. According to the prion hypothesis, TSEs are caused by infectious agents known as prions, which consist mainly, if not entirely, of an abnormal disease-associated form of the prion protein $(\mathrm{PrP})$ referred to as $\mathrm{PrP^{Sc}}$ (Prusiner, 1998). TSEs are characterized by the conversion of host-encoded cellular prion proteins $(\mathrm{PrP^{C}})$ into its pathogenic isoforms $(\mathrm{PrP^{Sc}})$, which accumulate in the central nervous system. The change in protein folding structure leads to the characteristic resistance of $\mathrm{PrP^{Sc}}$ towards inactivation. As a correlation between TSE infectivity and the presence of $\mathrm{PrP^{Sc}}$ has been shown, $\mathrm{PrP^{Sc}}$ is considered as a reliable marker of TSE infection (Beekes et al., 1996; Wadsworth et al., 2001). The biochemical detection of $\mathrm{PrP^{Sc}}$ remains the gold standard for the diagnosis of prion diseases.

Contextual materials: Bovines have long-been recognized as a key contributor to human schistosomiasis in Asia (Gray et al., 2007; Guo et al., 2006), and emerging evidence suggests they may be contributing to human schistosomiasis in Africa (Colley and Loker, 2018). Schistosomiasis is among the most burdensome helminth infections worldwide, with transmission being reported in a total of 78 countries in 2018 and approximately 230 million people in need of preventative treatment (World Health Organization, 2020). Although great strides have been made in the last few decades in global schistosomiasis control (World Health Organization, 2020), pockets of reemergent or persistent transmission highlight the need for careful consideration of possible local drivers of transmission (Kittur et al., 2019; Song et al., 2016). A poignant example is found in Schistosoma japonicum transmission in China, where despite well-established control programs and considerable progress towards elimination since the mid-1950s (Xu et al., 2016), a national report highlighted that there remained 450 endemic counties in 2020, a quarter of which had not achieved elimination criteria by year's end (Zhang et al., 2021). S. japonicum is transmitted by at least 40 species of wild and domestic mammals (Gray et al., 2009b), and animal activities near likely transmission sites may be important sources of reemergence and persistence. Although there are several domesticated and wild animals that can carry and transmit S. japonicum, (Li et al., 2015; Van Dorssen et al., 2017), estimates from Eastern China suggest that bovines may be responsible for as much as  $75\%$  of human transmission (Guo et al., 2006). This substantial contribution is thought to be related to the high degree of environmental overlap between humans and bovines during agricultural production, as well as the large amount of fecal output of bovines, which is estimated to be as high as 100 times that of human fecal production each day (Gray et al., 2009b; He et al., 2001; Ross et al., 2001). Additionally, the high frequency of livestock movement via the livestock trade within mountainous regions of China may facilitate the spread of S. japonicum infections across the region (Zheng et al., 2000; Zhou et al., 2012).

B: Predominantly mosquito-borne spread between bovines and humans, enhanced by higher bovine body temperature that accelerates larval development
C: Exclusive infection of bovines by a bovine-adapted S. japonicum lineage combined with absence of other mammalian reservoirs, making bovines the sole amplifying host
D: High environmental overlap with humans during agricultural work coupled with disproportionately large bovine fecal output (on the order of 100× human daily production)

Contextual materials: Amidst the overarching resemblance in mammary gland morphology and activity, a notable discrepancy in mammary predisposition to tumorigenesis emerges within various members of the mammalian class, suggesting differences in the stringency of controlling normal development and homeostasis. This discrepancy can be broadly categorized according to dietary preference: mammals belonging to the carnivore/omnivore taxa are susceptible to breast cancer, whereas herbivores are much less exposed (reviewed in [18, 19]). For example, mammary tumors are the most common neoplasm in female dogs, with up to  $50\%$  being malignant [20]. In cats, mammary tumors account for about  $17\%$  of all neoplasms, with  $80 - 90\%$  being malignant [21]. Wild carnivores, such as jungle cats, jaguars, leopards, lions, and tigers also develop mammary tumors, which exhibit morphological patterns similar to those in human breast cancer [19]. In contrast, mammary tumors have rarely been reported in domestic mares [22, 23], cows (Table 1), ewes [24], goats, or sows [25]. Mammary cancer is also rare in zoo and freeranging ungulates [26-28]. These significant differences in mammary gland tumor development may have contributed to the generally lower mortality rates observed in clovenhooved domestic or zoo mammals—compared to carnivores [29]. Pigs are cloven-hoofed animals and omnivores, capable of consuming both plant and animal matter. Notably, there are significant morphological similarities between their mammary glands and the human breast. A review of the literature by Morey-Matamalas and colleagues [30] highlights that naturally occurring mammary tumors are rare in pigs. However, porcine epithelial cells have been shown to develop neoplasia following oncogenic transformation and subsequent injection into mouse mammary glands [31]. This observation emphasizes the critical influence of the host environment on tumorigenesis and suggests that pigs may occupy an intermediate position between carnivores and herbivores in their susceptibility to mammary cancer.

question:
Contextual materials: Mycobacterium bovis (M. bovis), the causal agent of bovine tuberculosis (bTB), is an intracellular bacterium that causes heavy economic losses in bovine livestock production and represents a public health problem. M. bovis infects numerous mammals, including cattle, goats, dogs, pigs, lions, elephants, badgers, possums, deer, bison, and humans. The effects of M. bovis infection are variable; while recent infections do not induce notable changes, animals with chronic infection may develop weight loss, loss of appetite, and weakness, especially zoo animals [1]. In cattle, infection occurs mainly through the inhalation or ingestion of the bacterium, and severe infection causes loss of appetite and weight, and decreases productive parameters [2,3].
question: Which option best describes **Mycobacterium bovis** with respect to its **host spectrum**, **intracellular lifestyle (pathogenic niche)**, and the **common routes by which cattle become infected**?
A: An obligate extracellular bacterium largely restricted to bovids, transmitted in cattle primarily via arthropod vectors, typically causing rapid and uniform clinical disease
B: A virus infecting primarily zoo animals and rarely cattle, transmitted mainly by direct skin contact, with early infections commonly producing marked clinical signs
C: An intracellular bacterium confined to cattle and goats, transmitted chiefly through vertical (transplacental) spread, with severe infection typically increasing productive parameters
D: An intracellular bacterium with a broad mammalian host range including humans, transmitted in cattle mainly by inhalation or ingestion, with chronic infection potentially leading to weight loss, anorexia, and weakness

question:
Contextual materials: Campylobacter fetus subsp. fetus is frequently isolated from the intestinal tract of asymptomatic cattle, goats, and sheep. In animals,  $C$  fetus subsp. fetus exhibits a tropism for placental and reproductive tract tissues and is one of the major causes of sporadic and epidemic septic abortions (Viejo et al. 2001; Iraola et al. 2012).  $C$  fetus subsp. fetus can attach in an irreversible way to bull spermatozoa and affect sperm quality (Cagnoli et al. 2020). The diseases produced by  $C$  fetus subsp. fetus generate considerable economic losses, representing a significant problem in animal production (Mshelia et al. 2010). Heifers infected with  $C$  fetus showed a light inflammatory reaction with few mononuclear and polymorphonuclear cells distributed diffusely beneath the epithelia of vagina and cervix, and moderate endometritis and salpingitis (Cipolla et al. 1994). Such light inflammation reaction can be due to the composition of the external membrane of microorganisms.  $C$  fetus possesses lipooligosaccharides (LOS) instead of lipopolysaccharide (LPS) (Preston and Penner 1987; Moran et al. 2002). Also, it has a protein surface layer known as S-layer, which protects  $C$  fetus against complement and opsonization-phagocytosis response; it also prevents recognition by host innate immune system (Blaser et al. 1987; Fogg et al. 1990; Blaser et al. 1993).
question: A heifer infected with *Campylobacter fetus* subsp. *fetus* shows only mild, widespread subepithelial inflammation in the vagina and cervix, yet the bacteria persist within reproductive tissues. Which pairing of bacterial surface characteristics best accounts for the reduced inflammatory stimulation and the organism’s ability to avoid complement- and opsonization-mediated clearance?
A: Expression of a polysaccharide capsule plus secretion of IgA protease that blocks mucosal antibody binding
B: Replacement of LPS with LOS plus an S-layer that inhibits complement and opsonization-phagocytosis
C: Replacement of LOS with LPS plus fimbrial adhesins that irreversibly bind bull spermatozoa and trigger neutrophil recruitment
D: Presence of LPS with a highly endotoxic lipid A plus an S-layer that amplifies TLR4-mediated cytokine release

Contextual materials: In the public health context,  $M.$  tuberculosis and  $M.$  bovis have the greatest impact, causing tuberculosis, an infectious disease of global distribution that shows chronic evolution and affects humans, domestic and wildlife animals[9-12]. In 2015, the WHO global report revealed about 9.6 million new cases of human tuberculosis, and 1.5 million deaths. The same organization reported that, in 2014, tuberculosis ranked by the first time as a major infectious disease[14]. It is estimated that  $M.$  bovis is the causal agent of human tuberculosis in about  $10 - 15\%$  of the cases in developing countries, and in about  $1 - 2\%$  of the cases in developed countries[11,15]. question: A public health analyst is setting priorities and needs to identify (i) the primary Mycobacterium species affecting both people and animals, (ii) the main reasons tuberculosis is considered a re-emerging and significant threat, and (iii) how much *M. bovis* is estimated to account for human tuberculosis cases in developing compared with developed countries. Contextual materials: The BoHV-4 gene expression cascade is similar to that of other herpesviruses and comprises immediate early (IE), early (E), and late (L) gene expression. Activation of L gene expression requires DNA synthesis [3], and these genes give rise to the structural components of the virion.
question: In the course of BoHV-4 infection, which sequence of events and dependency pattern best matches the typical herpesvirus gene-expression cascade?
A: Immediate early proteins require de novo viral gene expression for transcription; once produced, they directly initiate late gene expression independently of DNA synthesis

C: Early genes are transcribed first in the absence of de novo viral gene expression; immediate early proteins are produced only after DNA replication begins, enabling late gene expression
D: Late structural genes are expressed at 2–4 hpi without requiring viral DNA synthesis, and they activate early genes involved in DNA replication

question:
Contextual materials: Bovine papillomavirus (BPV) is a widespread oncogenic virus found worldwide belonging to the Papillomaviridae family, which displays tropism for squamous epithelial and mucosal tissues. These viruses are associated with benign and malignant epithelial lesions. Specifically, BPV presents a double-stranded circular DNA, not coiled, with approximately $8\mathrm{kb}$, surrounded by an icosahedral capsid consisting of 360 copies of the L1 protein of $55\mathrm{kDa}$, 72 capsomeres arranged in approximately 12 copies of the L2 protein, $39\mathrm{kDa}$ [1-8]. The papillomavirus genome is divided into three regions: early, late, and noncoding long control region (LCR), separated by two polyadenylation sites [3]. The early control region occupies $50\%$ of the viral genome and encodes E1, E2, E3, E4, E5, E6, and E7 proteins. The late control region occupies $40\%$ of the genome and contains the genes that codify L1 and L2 capsid proteins and LCR, which comprises $10\%$ of the genome, with 850 bp. However, it also contains the origin of replication and the binding sites of multiple transcription factors [3]. Oncoproteins encoded by BPV are involved in several steps of the cell transformation [1, 9].
question: A virus lacking an envelope is described as having an icosahedral capsid composed of 72 capsomeres and carrying an approximately 8 kb circular double-stranded DNA genome organized into early, late, and a noncoding long control region (LCR). A: Capsid: 360 copies of a 55 kDa major protein plus ~12 copies of a 39 kDa minor protein; Genome: early region ~50% encoding E1–E7, late region ~40% encoding L1/L2, LCR ~10% (~850 bp) containing the origin of replication and transcription factor binding sites
B: Capsid: 360 copies of a 39 kDa major protein plus ~12 copies of a 55 kDa minor protein; Genome: early region ~50% encoding L1/L2, late region ~40% encoding E1–E7, LCR ~10% lacking replication origins but containing polyadenylation sites only
C: Capsid: 12 capsomeres each containing 72 copies of a 55 kDa protein; Genome: early region ~10% (~850 bp) encoding E1–E7, late region ~40% encoding transcription factor binding sites, LCR ~50% encoding L1/L2
D: Capsid: 72 copies of a 55 kDa major protein plus ~360 copies of a 39 kDa minor protein; Genome: early region ~40% encoding L1/L2, late region ~50% encoding E1–E7, LCR ~10% encoding structural proteins and polyadenylation signals

question:
Contextual materials: Papillomaviruses (PVs) are non-enveloped DNA viruses and among the most widespread animal viruses. Host-specific PVs have been identified in mammals, reptiles and birds (Bernard et al., 2010). Approximately 180 different human and 160 animal-specific PVs have been characterized so far; 21 of these are bovine in origin. Phylogenetic studies indicate that PVs and their hosts co-evolve. They are therefore highly host-specific viruses that usually do not cross species barriers. New variants, however, emerge if mutations accumulate within the virus genome. Closely related PVs are found in different host species indicating possible cross-species infection, which may lead to the emergence of new PV types (Gottschling et al., 2011). To date the only PVs clearly documented to infect more than one species are bovine PV types 1, 2, and 13 (BPV1, BPV2, and BPV13) of the genus Deltapapillomaviruses. These types cause fibropapillomas in bovines and are associated with skin tumours, termed sarcoids, in equids
question: A papillomavirus obtained from a skin tumour is shown to replicate effectively in both bovine cells—where it induces fibropapillomas—and equid cells—where it leads to sarcoids. Considering that papillomaviruses typically co-evolve with their hosts and are usually host-restricted, which classification most appropriately applies to this virus, and what does this suggest about its epidemiological significance?
A: A typical host-restricted bovine papillomavirus, implying the equid tumour most likely results from convergent pathology without infection
B: A bovine Deltapapillomavirus (e.g., BPV1/2/13), implying a rare but documented capacity for cross-species infection that can generate new PV types
C: A non-bovine alphapapillomavirus, implying broad host range is expected and co-evolution is not a major driver of PV phylogeny
D: An equid-specific papillomavirus, implying bovine fibropapillomas arise primarily from spillback after adaptation in equids

question:
Contextual materials: Astroviruses (AstVs) are a group of small, non-enveloped RNA viruses with an icosahedral capsid of $27 - 30\mathrm{nm}$ in diameter (Matsui and Greenberg, 1996) with a peculiar five- or six-pointed star shaped appearance when observed by negative staining electron microscopy (Caul and Appleton, 1982). The family Astroviridae has been classified by International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses $(\mathrm{ICTV})^{1}$ into two genera, namely Mamastrovirus and Avastrovirus known to infect mammalian and avian species, respectively. The genome length is 6.8 to $7.9\mathrm{kb}$ and includes a $5^{\prime}$ untranslated region (UTR), followed by three open reading frames (ORFs) namely ORF1a, ORF1b and ORF2, a $3^{\prime}$ UTR and a poly-A tail. There is a frame shift between ORF1a and ORF1b. ORF1a and ORF1b encode nonstructural proteins, a serine protease, and an RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp). ORF2 is expressed from a subgenomic RNA and encodes the viral capsid protein (Mendez and Arias, 2007).
question: How does the presence of ORF1a, ORF1b, and ORF2 in the astrovirus genome—featuring a ribosomal frameshift between ORF1a and ORF1b and expression of ORF2 via a subgenomic RNA—most directly affect the way viral proteins are produced?
A: The frameshift separates structural and nonstructural gene expression by forcing ORF2 to be translated only when ORF1a translation terminates at the poly-A tail
B: The frameshift ensures ORF1b is translated in a different cellular compartment than ORF1a, preventing RdRp synthesis until after capsid assembly from ORF2
C: The frameshift enables translation of a fused ORF1a–ORF1b polyprotein that includes the RdRp, while ORF2 is produced from a subgenomic RNA to generate the capsid protein
D: ORF1a and ORF1b are translated exclusively from subgenomic RNA to produce the serine protease and RdRp, whereas ORF2 is translated directly from genomic RNA to form the capsid
