question:
Contextual materials: The silver homolog premelanosome protein (PMEL, alternative names: Pmel-17, SILV, gp100 and ME20) has an important function in pigmentation of vertebrates. It is known that the protein is responsible for fibril formation within eumelanosomes [1], and it determines the elliptical eumelanosomal shape [2]. In contrast, pheomelanosomes show no fibril formation presumably due to the lack of PMEL expression [3]. The fibrillary structures laterally assemble into sheets, which serve as a matrix for eumelanin deposition (reviewed by Watt and co-workers [4]). Mutations in the PMEL gene are associated with coat color dilution in the mouse [5], chicken [6], dog [7] and horse [8]. In cattle, PMEL function seems to be unique because effects of genetic variants are not restricted to eumelanic coat color dilution as reported for other vertebrates. The non-synonymous mutation  $PMELc.64G > A$  (NM_001080215.2) in the signal peptide region of the bovine PMEL protein (NP_001073684) is causative for the Dilution locus (https://omia.org/OMIA001545/9913/), associated with extreme coat color dilution in the Charolais cattle breed [9]. A three-base-pair deletion c.50_52delTTC also in the N-terminal region of the bovine PMEL protein is responsible for coat color dilution in Highland and Galloway breeds [10]. These mutations in the bovine PMEL gene affect eumelanic as well as pheomelanic pigmentation [9-11]. This is remarkable because in other species pheomelanosomes are assumed to lack PMEL expression [3]. Furthermore, the PMEL locus has been identified as one component of a complex interaction of three loci underlying the genetic defect "rat tail syndrome" (RTS) in cattle (https://omia.org/OMIA001544/9913/) [12]. RTS is exclusively expressed in animals with a eumelanic background. This genetic defect was observed in calves produced by crossing animals from German Holstein with animals from the Charolais breed. The calves have short, curly, sometimes sparse hair, and a lack of normal tail hair development. Besides substantial effects on the hair structure, this defect is also associated with genetically-determined variation in coat color; animals with the RTS phenotype exhibit a darker grey (charcoal) coat color than animals without RTS phenotype.
question: Which explanation best accounts for why PMEL mutations in cattle can lighten both eumelanin- and pheomelanin-based coat colors, while the general vertebrate view holds that pheomelanosomes do not form PMEL-driven fibrils?
A: In cattle, PMEL likely influences a shared upstream melanogenic or melanosome-biogenesis step used by both eumelanosomes and pheomelanosomes, so signal-peptide/N-terminal PMEL variants can affect both pigment types even if fibril formation is classically linked to eumelanosomes
B: The dilution phenotypes attributed to PMEL in cattle are best explained by tight linkage to an adjacent gene controlling melanocortin receptor signaling, making PMEL itself dispensable for pigmentation changes
C: Bovine pheomelanosomes likely contain abundant PMEL fibrils identical to eumelanosomes, so dilution reflects direct loss of fibril scaffolding in pheomelanosomes rather than any cattle-specific regulatory divergence
D: Because PMEL determines eumelanosome ellipticity, bovine pheomelanosomes must be elliptical to incorporate pheomelanin; PMEL mutations therefore selectively block pheomelanin polymerization while leaving eumelanin deposition largely intact

question:
Contextual materials: Neospora caninum is a heteroxenic apicomplexan parasite which belongs to the coccidian cyst-forming Sarcocystidae family (Lindsay and Dubey 2020). This family includes other important representatives of the phylum Apicomplexa for domestic, wild animal and human health, such as Toxoplasma gondii, Sarcocystis suihominis or Besnoitia besnoiti. N. caninum is a primary cause of abortion in bovines as well as other small ruminant species and has a substantial economic impact on livestock industry (Reichel et al. 2013). Since N. caninum is an obligate intracellular parasite, asexual formation of offspring stages (tachyzoites) strictly occurs in and depends on nucleated host cells. In vivo, N. caninum preferentially infects endothelium but may also invade other nucleated cell types, thereby provoking major changes in host cell functions (Horcajo et al. 2017; Velásquez et al. 2019; Regidor-Cerrillo et al. 2020) and finally leading to cell lysis. In this context, primary bovine endothelial cells have been proven as suitable for  $N$ . caninum in vitro replication, allowing high proliferation rate of tachyzoites
question: Which option best combines *Neospora caninum*’s heteroxenic, obligate intracellular life cycle with the essential requirement for nucleated host cells that limits its asexual replication and informs the design of an appropriate in vitro culture method?
A: As a heteroxenic apicomplexan, it can complete tachyzoite amplification extracellularly provided serum factors are sufficient, making anucleate cells a permissive substrate
B: Belonging to Sarcocystidae implies that the asexual stages preferentially develop in erythrocytes, which explains why bovine blood cell preparations are optimal for tachyzoite expansion
C: Because it is an obligate intracellular parasite whose tachyzoites form asexually only within nucleated host cells, cultures enriched for primary bovine endothelial cells support high in vitro tachyzoite proliferation
D: Its major pathogenic effect in bovines is independent of cell invasion, so endothelial tropism is incidental and does not influence suitability of endothelial cultures for replication

question:
Contextual materials: Feline leukemia is considered to be a severe disease that can progress to a fatal illness faster than FIV infection [4]. FeLV infection results in several different disease outcomes (reviewed in [5]). An unknown percentage of infected cats can control the infection in the initial stages and avoid the virus from spreading to target tissues ("abortive infection"). Many cats develop a "regressive infection", in which the immune response partially contains the virus and viremia persists only for a few weeks. In some of these cats, the viremia is longer, and the virus infects haemopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow, where it can remain latent as proviral DNA integrated in the cellular genome. In approximately one third of all infected cats, the early immune response is unable to block the virus, and a massive replication and spread of the virus is produced, including the infection of hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow; this condition is called "progressive infection", and cats become persistently viremic. Eventually the infection progresses to the development of related neoplastic (such as leukemia and lymphoma) and non-neoplastic (such as anemia, gingivostomatitis, and enteritis) diseases [4,6]. Usually, FeLV-infected  $(\mathrm{FeLV}+)$  cats die within 1 to 3 years after the initial diagnosis due to all the pathologies and clinical complications the cats develop [5], mostly produced by secondary infections that may arise because of immunodeficiency.
question: Which FeLV infection course involves an early inability of the immune system to contain the virus, leading to extensive viral replication with infection of bone-marrow hematopoietic stem cells, followed by persistent viremia and a heightened risk of neoplastic and non-neoplastic diseases within a few years?
A: Abortive infection
B: Progressive infection
C: Regressive infection with brief viremia and proviral latency restricted to non-hematopoietic tissues
D: Regressive infection with viremia limited to a few weeks and no potential for proviral integration

However, differences in the nerves supplying the shoulder and antebrachium may reflect differing prey capture strategies between the subfamilies. In  $P$  uncia, an extensive musculus (m.) subscapularis with multiple pennations is innervated by a larger number of nn. subscapulares, deriving from more spinal cord levels than in  $F$  catus. C6 continues to become n. suprascapularis in both taxa; however, in  $F$  catus, it also gives branches that join with C7, while in  $P$  uncia, it is dedicated to musculi (mm.) supraspinatus, infraspinatus, and a small branch to cervical musculature. In  $F$  catus, nervus (n.) medianus receives direct contributions from more ventral rami than  $P$  uncia, possibly reflecting a greater reliance on manual dexterity in prey capture in the former. question:
Contextual materials: The feline calicivirus (FCV) belongs to the family Caliciviridae and is a respiratory pathogen widely prevalent in felines. C: Recovered kittens can continue shedding FCV via saliva and nasal secretions after symptoms improve, sustaining efficient horizontal spread
D: Only kittens aged 6–84 days shed infectious virus; once beyond this window they are noninfectious regardless of secretions

question:
Contextual materials: FIP is considered to be the most common infectious disease of the central nervous system (CNS) in cats [7,8], and up to 30% of cats with FIP are affected by neurological involvement [9-12]. Typical lesions involve both the brain and spinal cord and usually are surface-related and multifocal. They include meningitis, choroid plexitis, ependymitis, and periventriculitis, which can lead to increase of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) viscosity and obstructive hydrocephalus or hydromyelia [10,13-16]. Depending on their localization, these lesions can manifest clinically as seizures, ataxia, hyperesthesia, cranial nerve deficits, central vestibular signs, or behavioral changes [9,10,15-19]. CSF changes such as neutrophilic or pyogranulomatous pleocytosis and elevated protein concentration are common [10,17,20], but analysis can as well be unremarkable [16]. Presence of typical CSF changes increase suspicion of FIP, but findings are not diagnostic for FIP and can also be seen with other inflammatory CNS diseases [20,21] and in hypertensive encephalopathy with disruptive vascular disease [22].

Contextual materials: Cyclo-oxygenase-2 (COX-2) is an inducible enzyme that belongs to the prostaglandin H-synthase family. It catalyzes the rate-limiting step in prostanoid biosynthesis, a process known for its involvement in tumor progression and dissemination (1). During oncogenesis, the tumor microenvironment alters the essential functions of COX-2, inducing its overexpression. Encoded by a fast-response gene, this enzyme acts early to promote increased cell survival, enhanced tumor cell invasiveness, stimulation of neovascularization, and evasion from the host's immune system. This facilitates angiogenesis and proliferation, allowing for malignant transformation and rapid somatic evolution (1-3). Through biomolecular studies, it is currently known that in breast cancer, this molecule is responsible for increasing the survival of tumor cells by stimulating growth, invasion, angiogenesis, and downregulating tumor apoptosis (4-9).

B: A housekeeping mitochondrial dehydrogenase that drives oxidative phosphorylation, indirectly reducing tumor cell survival by increasing apoptosis and decreasing proliferation
C: An inducible lipoxygenase that controls the final step of leukotriene biosynthesis, acting late in tumorigenesis to enforce immune recognition and limit malignant dissemination

Contextual materials: During the last decade the availability of molecular techniques to detect provirus (DNA) and free plasma virus (RNA) has enhanced our understanding of the pathogenesis of FeLV infection. It has become apparent that antigen detection is a relatively insensitive indicator of infection and that cats previously considered to have recovered using conventional techniques can harbour low levels of virus. Following experimental exposure most cats show evidence of persistent, transcriptionally active virus.[10-15] In the field, up to  $10\%$  of antigen-negative cats test positive for provirus in peripheral blood by polymerase chain reaction (PCR).[10,16-18] The absence of viral RNA in the saliva of  $96\%$  of provirus-positive/antigen-negative cats, the success of test-and-removal programs that relied on antigen detection to identify 'infection' cats and the results of attempted experimental  transmission from latently infected cats,[4,17,19] suggest that regressive infection, characterised by absent antigenaemia and low, transient proviral load,[15] does not play a major role in natural transmission. The potential of FeLV to contribute to disease in antigen-negative cats requires clarification. While some epidemiological data demonstrate an increased risk of lymphoma and reduced survival in FeLV-exposed, antigen-negative cats compared with cats never exposed to the virus,[5,20,21] the results of immunohistochemical and molecular studies to date have yielded conflicting results.[22-28]

question:
Contextual materials: Body mass evolution in mammals has been a focus of study since Cope first suggested that there was a directed trend towards larger body mass throughout the Cenozoic Era (Cope, 1887). More recent studies have come to question whether Cope's Rule applies broadly across large clades, with suggestions that the apparent increases in body mass could be associated with an increase in variance, with no increase in smaller body sizes (i.e., a passive trend, Cope's rule sensu lato), and that only size increase in both lower and upper bounds, an active trend, should be recognized as Cope's rule sensu stricto (Stanley, 1973; McKinney, 1986; Gould, 1988; McShea, 1994; Arnold et al., 1995; Novack-Gottshall and Lanier, 2008). Alongside these epistemological refinements, which improve the ability to derive process from pattern of body size evolution, there have been vast improvements in analytical tools which allow for rigorous reconstructions of within-lineage trends (e.g., Ingram and Mahler, 2013; Uyeda and Harmon, 2014).

A: An increase in variance in body mass with no systematic shift in the distribution’s lower tail, producing an apparent increase in average size
B: A rise in mean body mass driven mainly by an expanding upper bound while the lower bound remains approximately constant
C: A within-lineage directional increase in body mass expressed as coordinated upward shifts in both the lower and upper bounds of body size
D: A clade-level increase in average body mass caused by preferential extinction of small-bodied taxa without any within-lineage size increase

question:
Contextual materials: The Tsushima leopard cat (TLC), also known as *Prionailurus bengalensis* euptilurus, is one of the most endangered animal species in Japan [1]. The TLC has a weight of  $4.5\mathrm{kg}$  for males and  $3.5\mathrm{kg}$  for females, making it a small felid. A typical cat has a long and fat tail, a long trunk, shorter-than-typical legs, and its color ranges from chestnut brown to cream with faint brown spots [2]. It only inhabits Tsushima Island in the Nagasaki Prefecture [3]. The TLC tends to be abundant in the upper region of Tsushima, known as Kamijima. Approximately 200 to 300 TLCs lived on Tsushima Island until the 1970s [4]. According to the Japan Wildlife Research Center, the number of TLCs continues to decrease at approximately  $10\%$  every 10 years. Human activity in wildcat habitats is one of the biggest threats to their survival [5]. Another important factor is infectious diseases. Disease transmission between domestic cats and TLCs have been previously documented [4,6-8]. Several cases of TLCs being infected with diseases commonly associated with domestic cats, including the feline immunodeficiency virus (FIV) and Felis catus gammaderpesvirus1 (FcaGHV1), have been reported [3,4,6]. According to a study that utilized the Geographical Information System (GIS) data, FIV infection risk in TLCs is higher in areas densely populated with domestic cats than in areas sparsely populated with the species [1]. A previous study reported the prevalence of feline leukemia virus (FeLV) infection in domestic cats but not in TLCs; however, it was demonstrated that the virus could replicate in their cells [3]. A study reported the detection of the feline foamy virus (FFV) infection in Iriomote leopard cats (Prionailurus bengalensis iriomotensis) in Japan [9]. A single FFV infection has been shown to be associated with potential pathological changes in domestic cats [10]. A previous study reported histopathological changes in the kidney and lung after experimental FFV inoculation [11]. Another study found that cats with FFV infection had a higher risk of developing lymphoma compared to FFV-negative cats [12]. However, coinfections with other viruses have been documented [13-15].

Contextual materials: Mesenchymal stem cells (MSC), which differ from other somatic and pluripotent stem cells, have anti-inflammatory, tissue-protective, and anti-fibrotic properties [1]. In addition to the pathological conditions that depend on the species, the unsuccessful results in cats may be due to the lower biological activity of fMSC, the earlier loss of proliferative activity and stemness [8], and the poorer ability to produce bioactive mediators without stimulation [9].

question:
Contextual materials: Frequent encounters between domestic animals and wildlife, as a result of human-mediated encroachment and fragmentation of wildlife habitats, can be detrimental for wild populations, especially when endangered (Nyhus, 2016). Because domestic animals often outnumber wildlife hosts of shared pathogens, they can maintain the environmental circulation of pathogens that can drive smaller populations of wild animals to extinction. As an example, canine distemper virus initially spreading from domestic dogs to lions almost drove the local population to extinction in the Serengeti ecosystem (Cleaveland et al., 1995). Even after widespread dog vaccination had reduced the infection in dogs, transmission to lions still occurred (Viana et al., 2015), emphasizing the complexities of controlling an infection once spread into natural protected areas.
question: In an area where domestic animals vastly outnumber an endangered wild carnivore and both can transmit the same pathogen through direct contact, which situation most convincingly explains how infection can continue spilling over into the wild carnivore even after large-scale vaccination has lowered disease levels in domestic dogs?
A: Dog vaccination selects for a host shift that makes the pathogen incapable of infecting dogs, so transmission to lions must be maintained solely by lions without new introductions
B: Domestic vaccination lowers pathogen prevalence but does not eliminate environmental circulation; residual transmission chains can be sustained by repeated contact at the interface and stochastic introductions into the protected area
C: Vaccination increases pathogen virulence in domestic dogs, making occasional exposures sufficient to maintain endemicity in the wild carnivore despite reduced dog infection
D: Once the pathogen enters a protected area, it becomes obligately vector-borne, rendering domestic vaccination irrelevant to onward transmission in lions

question:
Contextual materials: Sperm cryopreservation allows for a long-term preservation of genetic materials facilitating offspring propagation using assisted reproductive technologies, that is artificial insemination (AI), in vitro fertilization (IVF), embryo transfer (ET) and intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI). However, changes in temperature during freezing and thawing injure sperm cells. Feline sperm cells are collected routinely from live animals by electroejaculation, artificial vagina or urethral catheterization (Zambelli & Cunto, 2006). Sperm cells can similarly be collected from epididymis and testis after castration or necropsy offering an alternative source of genetic material particularly important for endangered species of wild felids. As ICSI technique has demonstrated to be highly efficient in felids, the mission of the sperm cells is now only to carry intact DNA to the oocytes and other components of male fertility have significantly lower importance. Therefore, the evaluation of DNA integrity, for long neglected in this species, is nowadays significantly highlighted in addition to semen other basic traits, that is motility, morphology and acrosome and membrane integrity. Sperm DNA assessment is considered as a significant indicator to predict fertilization rates, embryo development competence and pregnancy outcomes (Tesarik et al., 2004). As sperm DNA damage is often the result of oxidative stress in the male reproductive tract, the potential contribution of antioxidative agent supplementation to sperm cryopreservation media has been widely evaluated in both domestic (Thuwanut et al., 2008; Thuwanut et al., 2010) and wild cats (Thuwanut et al., 2011).
question: In felids, given the high effectiveness of intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI), what is the primary reason for emphasizing sperm DNA integrity assessment when evaluating cryopreserved semen, rather than focusing mainly on parameters such as motility and acrosome integrity?
A: DNA fragmentation in felid sperm is primarily caused by mechanical shearing during urethral catheterization, so antioxidant supplementation has minimal relevance compared with collection method refinement
B: Cryopreservation-induced temperature shifts selectively disrupt mitochondrial ATP production without significantly affecting nuclear chromatin, so motility best predicts post-thaw fertility
C: ICSI largely bypasses sperm functional requirements for zona penetration and motility, making intact paternal DNA the principal remaining determinant of fertilization, embryo competence, and pregnancy outcomes
D: Because epididymal and testicular sperm are inherently resistant to oxidative stress, DNA integrity is less informative than morphology when predicting embryo development after ICSI

question:
Contextual materials: Feline coronaviruses (FCoVs) and feline caliciviruses (FCVs) are important pathogens of cats and generally cause mild, self-limiting localized infection in the intestinal tract or oral cavity and upper respiratory tract, respectively. However, these viruses can also cause a life-threatening systemic illness with a high fatality rate in cats. FCoV associated with a fatal disease in cats, feline infectious peritonitis (FIP), causes systemic pyogranulomatous inflammation in various organs, which subsequently progresses to fluid accumulation in the abdominal cavity and death. In contrast to the more common asymptomatic or mild enteritis caused by feline enteric coronavirus, the enteric biotype of FCoV, FIP is relatively uncommon in the general cat population, but it is the leading cause of death in young cats (1-3). In addition to the two biotypes of feline enteric coronavirus and FIP coronavirus, FCoVs are also classified into two serotypes, I and II. FCoV serotype I is more prevalent than serotype II, which appears to be derived from recombination with canine coronavirus in the spike (S) protein (4-8). Both serotypes can cause enteritis or FIP in domestic and wild feline populations, including wildcats, cheetahs, mountain lions, and leopards (9-11). Virulent, systemic FCV (vs-FCV) is associated with systemic infection with a mortality rate as high as  $67\%$  (12-16). Unlike FCV associated with acute upper respiratory tract infection and oral ulceration, vs-FCV infection is characterized by an expanded tissue tropism, causing facial and limb edema, vasculitis, and dysfunctions in multiple organs (12-16). Despite the importance of these virus infections in cats, no effective preventive measure is currently available (reviewed in reference 17), and treatment options for FIP and vs-FCV infections are limited to supportive therapy, due to the lack of specific antiviral drugs. Therefore, effective therapeutic measures, such as antiviral drugs, are direly needed to combat these viral infections in cats.

A: Feline enteric coronavirus biotype — primary cause of systemic pyogranulomatous inflammation with abdominal effusion and high fatality
B: FCoV serotype II — increased prevalence over serotype I due to adaptation in feline populations without recombination
C: FIP-associated FCoV — largely localized intestinal infection with self-limiting enteritis in most cats
D: Virulent systemic FCV (vs-FCV) — expanded tissue tropism leading to edema, vasculitis, and multi-organ dysfunction with high mortality

question:
Contextual materials: Radioresistance and radiotoxicity have been reported following cancer treatments in felines. Optimizing radiation doses to induce cytotoxic effects to only cancer cells and not normal cells is critical in achieving effective radiation therapy; however, the mechanisms of radiation resistance, radiotoxicity, and DNA damage response (DDR) in feline cells have not yet been elucidated. A DNA double-strand break (DSB) is the most toxic type of DNA damage induced by X-rays and heavy ion beams used in treating cancers. Crandell-Rees Feline Kidney (CRFK) cells is one of the most widely used cat cells in life science research. Here, we report that DSB-triggered senescence induced by X-rays is important in inhibiting the proliferation of CRFK cells. We demonstrated through cell proliferation assay that X-rays at doses 2 Gy and 10 Gy are toxic to CRFK cells that irradiating CRFK cells inhibits their proliferation. In X-irradiated CRFK cells, a dose-dependent increase in DSB-triggered senescence was detected according to morphological changes and using senescence-associated  $\beta$  galactosidase staining assay. Moreover, our data indicated that in CRFK cells, the major DDR pathway, which involves the phosphorylation of H2AX at Ser139, was normally activated by ATM kinases. Our findings are useful in the understanding of X-rays-induced cellular senescence and in elucidating biological effects of radiation, e.g., toxicity, in feline cells. Furthermore, our findings suggest that the CRFK cell line is an excellent matrix for elucidating radioresistance and radiotoxicity in cat cells.
question: In CRFK feline cells irradiated with X-rays, which sequence of molecular events most plausibly explains the reduced cell proliferation seen at 2 Gy and 10 Gy, while also reflecting the primary double-strand break DNA damage response pathway identified in the study?

B: Double-strand breaks activate ATM, which phosphorylates H2AX at Ser139, promoting a dose-dependent senescence program that suppresses proliferation
C: Base oxidation activates DNA-PKcs, causing H2AX phosphorylation at Thr68 and rapid cell-cycle re-entry that masks cytotoxicity at higher doses
D: X-ray–induced single-strand breaks activate ATR, leading to p53-independent apoptosis without involvement of H2AX modification

question:
Contextual materials: Cats have a desert origin and, because of this, naturally tend to concentrate their urine more than other domestic animals, so their urine is usually more saturated (Horwitz et al. 2008). This fact, associated with changes in urinary pH, means they are predisposed to the formation of crystals that precipitate, forming uroliths and hence urolithiasis (Houston et al. 2003). An increase in urinary pH  $(>6.4)$  favors struvite uroliths and a reduction  $(< 6.2)$  favors the oxalate form (Kruger & Allen 2000; Carciofi 2007). In general, the occurrence of struvite uroliths is more frequent in cats (Buffington et al. 1997; Osborne et al. 2009).
question: A cat is undergoing treatment for recurring urolithiasis. Urinalysis consistently reveals elevated urine specific gravity and a urinary pH of 6.6. Under these conditions, which type of urolith composition is most likely to be promoted?
A: Urate, because concentrated urine primarily promotes purine stone formation irrespective of pH
B: Calcium oxalate, because urine pH above 6.4 promotes oxalate crystallization
C: Struvite, because urine pH above 6.4 favors struvite precipitation in concentrated urine
D: Cystine, because alkaline urine and high specific gravity are classic drivers of cystinuria stones

question:
Contextual materials: Myiasis can be classified based on host-parasite relationships, that is whether the dipteran species cause obligatory or facultative myiasis. The species causing obligatory myiasis require a living host for their development, while those causing facultative only occasionally lay eggs or larvae on living hosts and usually develop on decaying matter. Facultative myiasis can be classified as primary, secondary and tertiary, based on the ability of the species to initiate the myiasis (primary) or to superimpose to pre-existing myiasis (secondary and tertiary). Myiasis can also be classified based on anatomical localization of the larva (or larvae) in the host, either external or internal: auricular, cutaneous, gastrointestinal, ophthalmic, oral and urogenital [6-8]. Besides these types, myiasis involving structures of the nervous system will be considered as "neurological" in this review and those involving structures of the respiratory system will be considered as "respiratory".

question:
Contextual materials: Feline calicivirus (FCV) is a small, nonenveloped, single positive-strand RNA virus that belongs to the genus Vesivirus of the family Caliciviridae [1]. Most felines (e.g., cats, tigers, and cheetahs) are susceptible, and infection in dogs has been reported in recent years [2, 3]. Kittens aged 1 to 12 weeks are mainly infected, which results in a mortality rate of $67\%$ [4, 5]. Infected animals present with oral ulcers, chronic stomatitis, rhinitis, conjunctivitis, and pneumonia [6-9]. The primary prevention method at present is vaccination. However, due to the high evolutionary rate of the FCV capsid protein, which results in as many as $1.3 \times 10^{-2}$ to $2.6 \times 10^{-2}$ substitutions per nucleotide per year [10], traditional vaccination cannot completely protect animals from reinfection with mutant or wild-type strains, even though FCV is considered to have only one serotype [11]. Therefore, it is necessary to develop a safe and effective antiviral drug as a monotherapy or as part of a combination treatment.
question: Which set of viral characteristics most clearly accounts for why vaccines might not completely stop cats from being reinfected with feline calicivirus, even though the virus is regarded as having a single serotype?

Contextual materials: Alpha-1-acid glycoprotein (AGP) is the major feline acute-phase protein (APP). It has both a high affinity for small hydrophobic molecules and immunomodulatory properties. In humans, the rate of AGP sialylation seems to protect from viral infections. The serum concentration of feline AGP increases in several pathophysiological conditions and it is used as a biomarker of inflammation for many inflammatory/infectious diseases, together with other APPs such as serum amyloid A. The most prominent increases have been recorded in cats with feline infectious peritonitis (FIP), a lethal disease caused by the feline coronavirus (FCoV), on which AGP is hyposialylated. Because of these huge increases, AGP is considered the most powerful biomarker of FIP, especially when the pre-test probability of this disease is high. Transient increases in both the serum concentration and the rate of sialylation of AGP have also been recorded in clinically healthy cats living in FCoV-endemic environments.
question: Which situation best accounts for AGP being a highly reliable indicator of feline infectious peritonitis (FIP) while also showing increases that can mislead diagnosis in certain circumstances?
A: AGP is inferior to serum amyloid A for FIP because AGP binds small hydrophobic molecules, which prevents any infection-related change in sialylation from being measurable
B: Both FIP and endemic exposure cause identical patterns of AGP hyperconcentration and hyposialylation, so AGP is useful only when pre-test probability is low
C: FIP typically causes profound AGP hyposialylation with marked hyperconcentration, whereas clinically healthy cats in FCoV-endemic environments may show only transient AGP increases accompanied by increased sialylation
D: FIP causes decreased AGP concentration with increased sialylation, whereas clinically healthy cats in FCoV-endemic environments show sustained AGP hyperconcentration with hyposialylation

Contextual materials: Gammaherpesviruses (GHVs) are double-stranded DNA viruses. They belong to the Herpesviridae family, which includes three subfamilies: Alpha-, Beta- and Gammaherpesvirinae [1,2]. GHVs can infect humans, establishing a lifelong persistent infection mostly without evident clinical signs [3]. Host immunity is supposed to eliminate the infection, but frequently the virus undergoes latency with potential reactivation. GHV reactivation is suspected during co-infections or when cell-mediated immunity is compromised. In the latter cases, the virus can cause severe diseases that can be potentially fatal [4,5]. Two human GHVs are known to promote tumorigenesis in humans: Epstein-Barr virus and Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus [6-9]. Epstein-Barr virus is commonly identified in adult human beings worldwide. The virus is normally innocuous; however, in a few cases, it can cause lymphomas, carcinomas or other types of cancer. Loss of T-cell immunity and genetic predisposition are thought to be critical risk factors for the oncogenic potential of the Epstein-Barr virus [4,5].
question: Which situation best accounts for why an Epstein–Barr virus infection that is usually symptom-free may develop into cancer in a small proportion of infected people?
A: Compromised T-cell–mediated immunity permits latent infection with periodic reactivation, allowing oncogenic processes to emerge especially in genetically predisposed hosts
B: A primary deficiency in humoral immunity leads to immediate lytic clearance failure, preventing latency and thereby increasing oncogenic integration
C: Enhanced cell-mediated immunity forces the virus into a deeper latent state that directly drives rapid tumorigenesis without reactivation
D: Co-infection triggers complete viral eradication, and the resulting sterile inflammation is sufficient to initiate EBV-independent carcinomas

question:
Contextual materials: Feline Infectious Peritonitis (FIP) is a systemic fatal disease affecting mostly young cats (Pedersen, 2014a) sustained by the feline coronavirus (FCoV), which commonly occurs in multicat environments. The FCoVs usually inhabit the intestinal tract (feline enteric coronavirus, FECV). During viral replication within the enterocyte, a mutated variant, also called FIP virus (FIPV) may be generated (Pedersen, 2014a). Whichever is the exact mutation, FIPV loses tropism for enterocytes and gains the capability to replicate inside macrophages (Kipar et al., 2010). Moreover, FCoV induces macrophage-monocyte proliferation in haemo-lymphatic tissues and thus allow a progressive viral adaptation to the replication within these cells (Kipar and Meli, 2014). Although both viral biotypes (FECV and FIPV) can spread systemically, only the FIPV may induce FIP, due to the higher rate of interactions between the virus and monocytes. Moreover, the host immune response has a pivotal role in the development of the disease. Indeed, the cell-mediated immunity seems to be protective. On the other hand, it is known that the humoral response induces development of antibodies that enhance the in vitro virus uptake in macrophages and this, in turn, contributes in vivo to the development of the clinical signs seen during the effusive (wet) form of the disease. The non-effusive (dry) form is considered as an intermediate status involving a partially effective cellular response (Pedersen, 2014a).
question: Which combination of viral behavior and immune response best accounts for a feline coronavirus–infected cat developing the effusive (wet) form of feline infectious peritonitis?
A: A mutated viral biotype with macrophage tropism emerges, and antibodies facilitate macrophage uptake, amplifying monocyte–virus interactions and clinical disease
B: A non-mutated enteric biotype remains restricted to enterocytes, while strong humoral immunity neutralizes virus and prevents systemic dissemination
C: A mutated viral biotype emerges but remains primarily enterocyte-tropic; partial cell-mediated immunity contains infection, yielding granulomatous dry lesions
D: Systemic spread occurs only with the enteric biotype, and robust cell-mediated immunity paradoxically enhances viral uptake into macrophages via Fc receptors

question:
Contextual materials: Feline calicivirus (FCV) is a small, unenveloped, single-stranded RNA virus of the Vesivirus genus of the calicivirus family. Both domestic cats and other members of the felidae family can be infected with FCV (Munson et al. 2004, Driciru et al. 2006, Harrison et al. 2007). Studies have also demonstrated FCV infection in dogs (Martella et al. 2002), which suggests a potential risk for cross-species transmission. FCV strains differ in tropism and virulence; therefore, infection presents with a wide range of clinical signs. Most strains induce a fairly characteristic, mild syndrome characterized by pyrexia, oral ulceration, and mild respiratory and conjunctival signs. However, some FCV strains are nonpathogenic, and others are more virulent than the most common strains, with the ability to induce more severe systemic disease. Several outbreaks of a severe acute systemic febrile disease with high mortality have been reported (Martella et al. 2002, Di Martino et al. 2009); most outbreaks occurred in the United States and Europe, and they were caused by particularly virulent strains of FCV (FCV-associated virulent systemic disease, FCV-VSD). The impact of this disease is not limited to cats, and its ability to infect wildcats should not be ignored.
question: Which further finding would best reinforce worries that a small, non-enveloped, single-stranded RNA virus in the Vesivirus genus (Caliciviridae)—one that can cause either mild oral/respiratory illness or a highly fatal virulent systemic febrile disease with outbreaks largely in the U.S. and Europe—might spread between species beyond members of the cat family?
A: Restriction of severe outbreaks to a single geographic region, implying local host adaptation
B: Presence of an envelope enabling fusion-mediated entry across a broad range of hosts
C: Documented infections in dogs despite primary circulation in domestic and wild felids
D: Uniform tropism and virulence across strains producing a consistent clinical syndrome

Contextual materials: Severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome (SFTS) is an emerging infectious disease characterized by acute onset of high fever, hemorrhagic tendency, gastrointestinal and neurologic symptoms, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytopenia (1-4). B: SFTS is caused by a nairovirus in the family Phenuiviridae; it is flea-borne with Xenopsylla cheopis as the predominant vector, and livestock species have not shown detectable viral RNA despite seropositivity in carnivores.

question:
Contextual materials: Feline immunodeficiency virus (FIV) Vif protein counteracts feline APOBEC3s (FcaA3s) restriction factors by inducing their proteasomal degradation. The functional domains in FIV Vif for interaction with FcaA3s are poorly understood. Here, we have identified several motifs in FIV Vif that are important for selective degradation of different FcaA3s. Cats (Felis catus) express three types of A3s: single-domain A3Z2, single-domain A3Z3, and double-domain A3Z2Z3. We proposed that FIV Vif would selectively interact with the Z2 and the Z3 A3s. Indeed, we identified two N-terminal Vif motifs (12LF13 and 18GG19) that specifically interacted with the FcaA3Z2 protein but not with A3Z3. In contrast, the exclusive degradation of FcaA3Z3 was regulated by a region of three residues (M24, L25, and I27). Only a FIV Vif carrying a combination of mutations from both interaction sites lost the capacity to degrade and counteract FcaA3Z2Z3. However, alterations in the specific A3s interaction sites did not affect the cellular localization of the FIV Vif protein and binding to feline A3s. Pulldown experiments demonstrated that the A3 binding region localized to FIV Vif residues 50 to 80, outside the specific A3 interaction domain. Finally, we found that the Vif sites specific to individual A3s are conserved in several FIV lineages of domestic cat and nondomestic cats, while being absent in the FIV Vif of pumas. Our data support a complex model of multiple Vif-A3 interactions in which the specific region for selective A3 counteraction is discrete from a general A3 binding domain.

C: Single-site disruption of either the Z2-specific N-terminal motifs (12LF13/18GG19) or the Z3-selective M24/L25/I27 segment is sufficient to eliminate counteraction of A3Z2Z3 because A3Z2Z3 requires a unique binding surface absent from residues 50–80
D: Mutations restricted to the A3-binding region (Vif residues 50–80) abolish binding and thereby specifically prevent degradation of A3Z2Z3 while leaving degradation of A3Z2 and A3Z3 intact

Contextual materials: Snake envenomation is a serious threat to many developed and developing countries. The injection of venomous toxin from snake to a victim evokes a chain of reactions which unless treated will pose threat to life of the victim. These toxins affect different physiological systems of the victims thereby leading to death. In addition, morbidity due to envenomation can cause many physical defects like amputation, necrosis and severe local damage [7].
question: Which categorization of snake venom constituents correctly matches each toxin group with the biochemical type suggested by its name and classification?
A: Phospholipase A2 (PLA2) — non-enzymatic; protease inhibitors — enzymatic
B: L-amino acid oxidases (LAAO) — non-enzymatic; protease inhibitors — enzymatic
C: Snake venom metalloproteases (SVMPs) — enzymatic; disintegrins — non-enzymatic
D: Three finger toxins — enzymatic; serine proteases — non-enzymatic

Contextual materials: Polyomaviruses are nonenveloped circular double-stranded DNA viruses that infect a variety of vertebrate host species. question:
Contextual materials: Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS) is a relatively rare, but frequently fatal disease associated with New World hantaviruses, most commonly Sin Nombre and Andes viruses in North and South America, respectively. It is characterized by fever and the sudden, rapid onset of severe respiratory distress and cardiogenic shock, which can be fatal in up to $50\%$ of cases. Currently there are no approved antiviral therapies or vaccines for the treatment or prevention of HPS. A major obstacle in the development of effective medical countermeasures against highly pathogenic agents like the hantaviruses is recapitulating the human disease as closely as possible in an appropriate and reliable animal model. To date, the only animal model that resembles HPS in humans is the Syrian hamster model. Following infection with Andes virus, hamsters develop HPS-like disease which faithfully mimics the human condition with respect to incubation period and pathophysiology of disease. Perhaps most importantly, the sudden and rapid onset of severe respiratory distress observed in humans also occurs in hamsters. The last several years has seen an increase in studies utilizing the Andes virus hamster model which have provided unique insight into HPS pathogenesis as well as potential therapeutic and vaccine strategies to treat and prevent HPS.

question:
Contextual materials: Rabbit hemorrhagic disease virus 2 (RHDV2) is a highly contagious and lethal pathogen that infects both domestic and wild lagomorphs (rabbits and hares). RHDV2 is a non-enveloped, icosahedral, single-stranded RNA virus of the genus Lagovirus, family Caliciviridae (Asin et al. 2021). The virus typically has a three- to nine-day incubation period and can cause fatal disease (up to  $80\%$  mortality rate) within two to four days of infection, and infected animals often show no obvious signs of disease before death (Le Gall-Reculé et al. 2013; OIE 2019). RHDV2 was first detected in France in 2010 and, in the 12 years since its discovery, has spread across five continents (Rouco et al. 2019; Hu et al. 2021; Katayama et al. 2021). It is hypothesized that the human-mediated movement of rabbits is partly responsible for the dissemination of RHDV2 globally (Mahar et al. 2018; Marschang et al. 2018; Rouco et al. 2019).

question:
Contextual materials: The cerebral cortex receives thousands of inputs from the sensory organs and uses them to create representations of the world and respond appropriately. With the exception of smells, all sensory signals travel through a part of the brain called the thalamus on their way to the cortex. The principal cells of the thalamus then relay this constant stream of information to the cerebral cortex in an orderly, topographical manner. When a neuron in the thalamus relays a signal to a neuron in the input layer of the cortex, the cortical neuron receiving the input can be excitatory or inhibitory, changing the nature of the signal. Figuring out the rules that govern the connections between the thalamus and the cortex is fundamental to understanding the transformation of sensory inputs that travel through this route. For example, how is it that activity of the whole visual cortex is driven by input from the thalamus when fewer than  $1 - 5\%$  of the synapses into the primary visual cortex originate in the thalamus (Douglas and Martin, 2004; Markov et al., 2011)? This is only possible if the thalamocortical synapses act cooperatively (Alonso et al., 1996; Swadlow and Gusev, 2001; Bruno and Sakmann, 2006).
question: A scientist is trying to explain how signals from the thalamus can activate the whole primary visual cortex even though thalamic connections make up only about 1–5% of the synapses there. Which mechanism best accounts for this seeming discrepancy in a way that fits what is known about thalamocortical connectivity and sensory signal transmission?
A: Thalamic relay neurons primarily target only inhibitory cortical neurons, so global cortical activation is produced by disinhibition rather than excitation
B: Most visual sensory signals bypass the thalamus and reach the cortex directly, so the 1–5% figure is misleading for effective drive
C: The thalamus provides a sparse but highly cooperative set of synapses whose temporally correlated activation can amplify cortical responses beyond what synapse counts alone predict
D: Thalamocortical projections are non-topographical and randomly distributed, ensuring uniform cortical activation through statistical averaging

question:
Contextual materials: Rabbit haemorrhagic disease viruses (RHDV) belong to the family Caliciviridae, genus Lagovirus europaeus, genogroup GI, comprising four genotypes GI.1-GI.4, of which the genotypes GI.1 and GI.2 are pathogenic RHD viruses, while the genotypes GI.3 and GI.4 are non-pathogenic RCV (Rabbit calicivirus) viruses. Among the pathogenic genotypes GI.1 and GI.2 of RHD viruses, an antigenic variant of RHDV, named RHDVa—now GI.1a-RHDVa, was distinguished in 1996; and in 2010, a variant of RHDV—named RHDVb, later RHDV2 and now GI.2-RHDV2/b—was described; and recombinants of these viruses were registered. Pathogenic viruses of the genotype GI.1 were the cause of a disease described in 1984 in China in domestic (Oryctolagus (O.) cuniculus domesticus) and wild (O. cuniculus) rabbits, characterised by a very rapid course and a mortality rate of  $90 - 100\%$ , which spread in countries all over the world and which has been defined since 1989 as rabbit haemorrhagic disease. It is now accepted that GI.1-RHDV, including GI.1a-RHDVa, cause the predetermined primary haemorrhagic disease in domestic and wild rabbits, while GI.2-RHDV2/b cause it not only in rabbits, including domestic rabbits' young up to 4 weeks and rabbits immunised with rabbit haemorrhagic disease vaccine, but also in five various species of wild rabbits and seven different species of hares, as well as wild ruminants: mountain muskoxen and European badger. Among these viruses, haemagglutination-positive, doubtful and harmful viruses have been recorded and described and have been shown to form phylogenogroups, immunotypes, haematotypes and pathotypes, which, together with traits that alter and expand their infectious spectrum (rabbit, hare, wild ruminant, badger and various rabbit and hare species), are the determinants of their pathogenicity (infectivity) and immunogenicity and thus shape their virulence. These relationships are the aim of our consideration in this article.

C: GI.2-RHDV2/b is restricted to adult domestic rabbits and cannot infect vaccinated animals, whereas GI.1a-RHDVa is the only genotype reported to infect hares and wild ruminants

question:
Contextual materials: Atherosclerosis, as the most common underlying cause of cardiovascular disease, is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in many populations [1,2]. Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory process involving multiple cell types and cytokines [3]. Its progression commences with LDL deposition, endothelial dysfunction, subendothelial accumulation of foam cells, and formation of fatty streaks, under the activation of pro-inflammatory agents [4]. As the plaque progression continues, vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMC) migrate into the intima and elaborate extracellular matrix. After decades, the fatty streak could progress into fibroatheroma lesions, characterized by the fibrous caps encompassing the lipid core [5]. At advanced stages, stable lesions have a small lipid core and a thick fibrous cap, while vulnerable lesions have the relatively thin fibrous cap and large lipid core. Once the fibrous cap rupture, a superimposed thrombosis could occlude the arterial lumens and disrupt blood flow, which is responsible for most morbidity and mortality of atherosclerosis. Overall, atherosclerosis could remain asymptomatic for decades before clinical manifestations even complicated lesions could be clinically overt, and some of the cases will only be diagnosed through a postmortem [7].
question: Which ordered set of steps best represents the transition from initial atherosclerotic development to an acute artery-blocking episode, and which plaque characteristic most greatly increases the likelihood of that episode?

B: Endothelial dysfunction → VSMC migration into intima with extracellular matrix deposition → fibroatheroma with fibrous cap over lipid core → thin fibrous cap with large lipid core → cap rupture leading to superimposed thrombosis and potential luminal occlusion
C: LDL deposition → immediate thick fibrous cap formation over a small lipid core → plaque stabilization → gradual luminal occlusion without thrombosis as the dominant cause of clinical events
D: Fatty streak formation → regression into stable lesion characterized by thin fibrous cap and large lipid core → cap rupture most often producing non-occlusive mural platelet aggregates with minimal flow disruption

question:
Contextual materials: Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase 1 (soluble) (PCK1) is a gluconeogenic gene that encodes the rate-limited enzyme PEPCK-C in gluconeogenesis (Hanson & Patel 1994). The role of  $PCK1$  in gluconeogenesis has been extensively reviewed (Hanson & Patel 1994), and it is well recognized that  $PCK1$  expression regulates plasma glucose level. For example, changing  $PCK1$  expression in the liver induces increased blood glucose (Valera et al. 1994) or hypoglycemia (Vidnes & Sovik 1976; She et al. 2000). Although  $PCK1$  has been linked to primarily gluconeogenesis, it has also been found in tissues that don't produce glucose, such as adipose tissue (Hanson & Reshef 2003; Reshef et al. 2003; Qu et al. 2016). Therefore, in addition to gluconeogenesis, other functions have been proposed for  $PCK1$ . Studies of the glyceroneogenesis have provided insight on the important role of  $PCK1$  in lipid metabolism. Glyceroneogenesis, which de novo synthesizes glycerol-3-phosphate from non-glucose or non-glycerol precursors, is a critical pathway for re-esterifying the free fatty acids released by adipose tissues during fasting conditions (Vaughan 1962; Ballard et al. 1967; Gorin et al. 1969).  $PCK1$  has been demonstrated to play important roles in this process. For example, She et al. (2000) found that mice with the deletion of  $PCK1$  in the liver presented a fatty liver because of the accumulation of fatty acid. Moreover, Olswang et al. (2002) reported that the deletion of  $PCK1$  expression in adipose tissue inhibited glyceroneogenesis and reduced triglyceride deposition. Thus, the role of  $PCK1$  in lipid metabolism is no less important than that in gluconeogenesis.
question: Which tissue-targeted gene knockout would be most likely to greatly decrease triglyceride storage in adipose tissue—while leaving liver glucose production largely unaffected—by blocking re-esterification of free fatty acids released during fasting due to impaired de novo synthesis of glycerol-3-phosphate from non-glucose substrates?
A: Adipose-specific deletion of PCK1
B: Liver-specific overexpression of PCK1
C: Liver-specific deletion of PCK1
D: Adipose-specific overexpression of PCK1

Contextual materials: Skeletal muscle is the largest and most important tissue in animals, accounting for about  $50\%$  of body weight [1,2]. question:
Contextual materials: IAV preferentially replicates in different tissues and organs in the host, and initial infection often depends on the linkage type of terminal sialic acid on glycoproteins expressed on the surface of cells. Viral hemagglutinin (HA) surface proteins bind to glycoprotein-linked sialic acid (SA) on the surface of host cells. The specific linkage of these sialic acids allows the virus to not only become specific to different host species, but also different tissues in these hosts. Humans express sialic acid  $\alpha$ -2,6 linked galactose (SA  $\alpha$ -2,6-Gal) surface molecules on epithelial cells in the upper airways, which is the site of replication for IAV in humans (Baum and Paulson, 1990; Couceiro et al., 1993). As such, strains of IAV that infect humans replicate in the upper airways. Birds, however, predominantly express SA  $\alpha$ -2,3-Gal in their digestive tracts and lungs (Costa et al., 2012). Strains of IAV which are adapted to replicate in birds preferentially bind these receptors over human SA  $\alpha$ -2,6-Gal receptors. Chickens also express  $\alpha$ -2,6-Gal in their intestinal tracts and lungs, whereas ducks only express these receptors in their lungs. Chickens also have a predominance of SA  $\alpha$ -2,6-Gal in their trachea whereas ducks have SA  $\alpha$ -2,3-Gal receptor dominance (Kuchipudi et al., 2009). As IAV has been known to jump host species, as is the case of avian IAV jumping to humans, this suggests that chickens may be responsible for propagating avian strains of influenza that can then infect humans. IAV can use other receptors such as phosphoglycans on host cells to gain entry and seems to depend on more than just SA linkages to enter cells (Byrd-Leotis et al., 2019).

B: Chicken digestive tract, because birds predominantly express SAα-2,3-Gal there, enforcing strict avian specificity

question:
Contextual materials: RANTES (Regulated upon Activation, Normal T-cell Expressed and Secreted) is a key pro-inflammatory cytokine that belongs to the CC-group among the CXC, CC, CX3C and C subfamilies of chemokines. In mammals, this small protein of approximately $8\mathrm{kDa}$ is produced by a wide variety of cell types such as lymphocytes, macrophages, fibroblasts, platelets, smooth muscle, endothelial, and epithelial cells (Schall et al., 1988; Appay and Rowland-Jones, 2001). In addition to the chemotaxis, they also mediate T-cell stimulation (Dairaghi et al., 1998). Studies have also shown that they can elicit inhibition of virus infection either through cellular receptor agonism, as reported in Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) infections (Zagury et al., 1998), or through the direct binding with envelope glycoproteins of viruses, as reported for human Herpes Virus (Nakayama et al., 2006).

B: A CC-group chemokine of ~8 kDa that can inhibit viral infection either by acting as a cellular receptor agonist (e.g., in HIV) or by directly binding viral envelope glycoproteins (e.g., herpesvirus)

D: A C-group chemokine of ~8 kDa produced mainly by neurons that inhibits herpesvirus by antagonizing viral DNA polymerase and has minimal chemotactic activity

question:
Contextual materials: DTMUV is a contagious virus that severely reduces egg production 1-3. Infected ducks show severe neurological signs, such as uncoordinated gait and a reluctance or inability to walk  $^{1,2}$ . The morbidity and mortality rate of infected ducks ranges 20 to  $50\%$  and 10 to  $30\%$ , respectively<sup>1</sup>. This virus was first isolated from infected ducks in China in  $2010^2$ . After the initial outbreak, it rapidly spread to other intensive duck farming countries, including Malaysia  $^{4}$  and Thailand  $^{1}$ . Until now, no approved vaccinations or sufficient therapeutics have been developed. DTMUV is a positive-sense single-stranded RNA virus classified in the genus Flavivirus in the Flaviviridae family, which includes other human neuropathogenic flaviviruses, such as Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), West Nile virus (WNV), and tick-borne encephalitis virus (TBEV). Similar to other neuropathogenic flaviviruses, DTMUV can also cause encephalitis in a variety of animals, including mammals  $^{3}$  and birds such as chickens  $^{4}$ , geese  $^{5,6}$ , sparrows  $^{7}$  and pigeons  $^{8}$ . Once DTMUV enters the central nervous system (CNS), infected birds typically show non-suppurative inflammation, including perivascular mononuclear cell infiltration and focal gliosis  $^{1,2,9}$ . Immunohistochemical analyses demonstrated that DTMUV antigen can be detected in cytoplasm of Purkinje cells in the cerebellum of infected ducks  $^{9}$ . Infected ducks also showed high expression of DTMUV RNA in the brains  $^{9,10}$ . This result indicated that duck neurons are the primary targets of DTMUV infection and replication. Despite the importance of neuropathogenicity of DTMUV, the mechanism by which DTMUV causes neuronal cell death has not yet been investigated.

question:
Contextual materials: Type I interferon (IFN) acts as the first line of defense against invading viral pathogens (Rasmussen et al., 2009; Schoggins and Rice, 2011). Once host molecular pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) recognize viral pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs), such as viral nucleic acids or proteins, a series of signaling pathways involving dozens of conserved adaptor molecules and kinases are activated rapidly, resulting in the expression of type I IFN (Akira et al., 2006; Medzhitov, 2007; Takeuchi and Akira, 2009). Type I IFN production during viral infection upregulated hundreds of interferon stimulated genes (ISGs) expression via Janus kinase/signal transducer and activation of transcription (JAK/STAT) signaling pathway, many of which could directly kill viruses within infected cells (Schoggins and Rice, 2011; Theofilopoulos et al., 2005). In this pathway, type I IFNs binding leads to IFN receptors oligomerization, which triggers phosphorylation of JAK molecules (Cohen et al., 1995; Levy and Darnell, 2002). Activated JAKs subsequently phosphorylate the key tyrosine residues within the intracellular domains of IFN receptors, which serve as docking sites for STAT proteins (Darnell et al., 1994). Thus, JAKs in turn phosphorylate both STAT1 and STAT2 proteins (Schindler et al., 1992). The phosphorylated STAT proteins dimerize, interact with IFN regulatory factor (IRF) 9, and then form the ISG factor 3 (ISGF3) complex (Qureshi et al., 1995). This ISGF3 complex then migrates to the nucleus, where it binds to IFN-stimulated regulatory elements (ISREs) in the ISG promoters, resulting in the transcription of hundreds of ISGs to limit virus replication and spread (Martinez-Moczygemba et al., 1997; Schoggins and Rice, 2011).

A: Dimerization of phosphorylated STAT1 and STAT2, which phosphorylates the IFN receptor tails to recruit IRF9
B: Phosphorylation of key tyrosine residues within the intracellular domains of IFN receptors by activated JAKs
C: Oligomerization of IFN receptors, which directly recruits IRF9 to the receptor complex
D: Nuclear translocation of STAT1/STAT2, which exposes ISREs and promotes IRF9 binding in the cytosol

Contextual materials: Stimulator of the IFN gene (STING) is a newly discovered key type I IFN positive regulatory factor and is also known as MPYS, mediator of IRF-3 activation (MITA), endoplasmic reticulum IFN stimulator (ERIS) or transmembrane protein 173 (TMEM173) [4-6]. STING is a membrane-related protein that contains four or five transmembrane regions, which are mainly located in the endoplasmic reticulum and partially located in mitochondria and mitochondria-associated membranes (MAMs) [4-7]. When STING is overexpressed in cells, IRF3 is activated and viral replication is suppressed [4,5]. RNA interference assays demonstrate that by reducing the expression of STING, the activation of IRF3 is inhibited and viral replication increases [4,5]. Bacteria and DNA viruses activate STING, but recent studies show that STING also plays an important role in inhibiting positive strand RNA viral replication [8-10]. STING functions downstream of RIG-I and MAVS and upstream of TBK1 and is considered a scaffold protein for the MAVS/tank binding kinase 1 (TBK1)/IRF3 complex when an RNA virus is infected and is capable of binding to RIG-I (rather than MDA5), MAVS, TBK1 and I $\kappa$ B kinase  $\varepsilon$  [7,11]. STING is a newly discovered regulatory molecule in the type I interferon pathway, and its immunological properties and antiviral properties require further study.

question:
Contextual materials: Estrogens belong to the gonadal steroid hormone family synthesized from cholesterol mainly in the ovaries, granulosa cells, and corpora lutea. They are also produced in other non-gonadal organs and tissues including the heart, liver, skin, brain, adipose tissue, and adrenal glands (1-4). The two main receptors found in poultry are estrogen receptor 1 (ESR1/ERα/ER1) and estrogen receptor 2 (ESR2/ERβ/ER2) which are found in the nuclear receptor superfamily (6-8). The ERs act as transcription factors to initiate gene transcription through estrogen response elements (EREs) in the target tissues and also interact with other transcription factors (9).

B: Estrogens primarily signal through ESR1 and ESR2, which are cytosolic enzymes that synthesize EREs as RNA intermediates to initiate transcription in target tissues

question:
Contextual materials: NDV is capable of infecting a wide variety of avian species, and at least 241 species from 27 of the 50 orders of birds have been found to be susceptible to natural or experimental infections with NDV [4]. The virulence of NDV strains varies greatly with the host. Among poultry, chickens and turkeys are the most susceptible, and ducks and geese are the least susceptible. Ducks and geese are generally considered to be natural reservoirs or carriers of NDV while being resistant to NDV strains, even those most virulent for chickens [1]. However, outbreaks of ND have frequently occurred in geese throughout China since 1997, causing devastating economic losses [5-9]. Many NDV strains of different virulences have been isolated from diseased and clinically healthy ducks [10-25]. Some isolates were pathogenic for ducks, and natural ND cases in ducks have been gradually increasing in recent years [10,11,14,16-19,21,23-25], indicating that ducks may be not just reservoirs and carriers of NDV but also susceptible to infection with the disease.
question: Which conclusion most effectively explains how ducks and geese can be considered NDV-resistant carrier reservoirs while still showing a growing number of natural Newcastle disease cases and outbreaks in these birds?
A: NDV virulence is host-dependent, and the circulation of strains with altered host range can render traditionally resistant reservoir species clinically susceptible without negating their carrier role
B: The apparent rise in disease among ducks and geese is most parsimoniously explained by misdiagnosis, since true NDV infection cannot occur naturally in reservoir hosts
C: Because chickens and turkeys are the most susceptible, ND outbreaks in geese must primarily reflect spillover of vaccine strains that are uniformly avirulent in waterfowl
D: If ducks and geese can be infected, they cannot be reservoirs; therefore, the earlier classification of them as carriers must have been based on experimental artifact rather than field evidence

Contextual materials: In mammals, TLR3 recognises double-stranded RNA from viral sources through its ectodomain to activate the down-steam pathway (Alexopoulou et al., 2001). Upon viral infection, phagocytes such as macrophages and dendritic cells take up virus-infected apoptotic cells. Viral RNAs may be released from these apoptotic cells in intracellular acidic compartments, such as phagosomes, by the action of lysosomal enzymes, and TLR3 is the receptor for viral RNAs and is indispensable for mounting anti-viral innate immune responses by inducing type I interferons (Alexopoulou et al., 2001; Hoebe et al., 2003; Iwasaki and Medzhitov, 2004). TLR3-deficient mice lacked the ability to optimise poly(A:U)-induced clonal T-cell expansion and prevented the production of interferon (IFN)- $\gamma$  and interleukin (IL)-12p40 (Sugiyama et al., 2008). TLR3 transmits signals through their corresponding adaptive proteins, and activates a series of transcription factors, such as interferon regulatory factor (IRF)-3, IRF-7, and nuclear factor-  $\kappa \mathrm{B}$  (NF- $\kappa \mathrm{B}$ ), which consequently leads to the production of type I IFNs and proinflammatory cytokines (Sweeney et al., 2010). Collectively, TLR3 plays a role in restricting the entry of viral nucleic acids pathogens in vertebrates. In avian species, TLR8 is non-functional and TLR9 is absent, and only TLR3 and TLR7 are involved in the recognition of RNA viruses.

question:
Contextual materials: Avian divers needed to solve the biomechanical conflict between their primary adaptation, aimed towards flight, and their secondary adaptation, for swimming underwater. The first conflict ensues from the low density of the avian body (due to the hollow bones, large air sacs, and layer of air trapped under the waterproof plumage), resulting in a high buoyancy that resists diving by pushing the diver upward towards the surface<sup>1-3</sup>. Consequently, many waterfowl swim on the water surface, but only a few are also adapted to swimming underwater. The second conflict involves the use of wings for propulsion in both air and water, which differ  $\sim 850$ -fold and  $\sim 55$ -fold in their density and viscosity, respectively, making large wings inefficient underwater and small wings inefficient for flight. The compromise of using the same wing for flying and swimming entails a toll on the efficiency of at least one of these forms of locomotion<sup>4,5</sup>. Most waterfowl avoid the second conflict by keeping their wings adapted for flight and swim exclusively using their webbed feet while the wings remain folded close to the body (but see Richman and Lovvorn<sup>6</sup>, for combined wing and foot propulsion underwater).
question: An avian species evolves to become specialized for underwater swimming while still maintaining powered flight. Considering that water is approximately 850 times denser and 55 times more viscous than air, which evolutionary modification would most directly reduce the inefficiency of using wings for propulsion underwater, while not addressing the buoyancy issue created by hollow bones, air sacs, and air trapped in the plumage?
A: Reducing wing area and shifting underwater propulsion primarily to webbed feet while keeping wings folded during dives
B: Increasing subplumage air trapping to enhance thermal insulation, which secondarily improves underwater thrust
C: Enlarging air sacs to decrease body density further, allowing easier submergence through reduced inertia
D: Increasing wing area to generate higher lift underwater, thereby reducing the need for foot propulsion

question:
Contextual materials: The interferon (IFN)-mediated innate immune response serves as the first line of host defense against invading viruses (Akira et al., 2006; Mogensen, 2009). Following pathogen detection and subsequent IFN production, IFN molecules bind to their cell-surface receptors and rapidly initiate a signaling cascade via the Janus kinase signal transducer and activator of transcription (JAK-STAT) pathway, leading to the induction of expression of a wide variety of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs) (Kisseleva et al., 2002; Schneider et al., 2014). Upon IFN binding, IFN receptors undergo conformational changes and subsequently form dimeric or oligomeric complexes, which lead to JAK apposition and transphosphorylation on specific tyrosine residues, releasing their intrinsic catalytic activity (Levy and Darnell, 2002; Piehler et al., 2012). The activated JAKs in turn phosphorylate tyrosine residues within the cytoplasmic domains of IFN receptors, providing binding sites for the Src-homology-2 (SH2) domain of the STAT proteins (Bousoik and Montazeri Aliabadi, 2018). After binding to the receptors, STAT proteins are phosphorylated by JAKs. Phosphorylated STATs dissociate from the receptor-JAK complexes, form homo- or heterodimers, and then translocate to the nucleus where they complex with other nuclear proteins and bind to IFN-stimulated response element (ISRE) and gamma-activated sequence (GAS) to regulate hundreds of ISGs expression (Sands et al., 2006). JAK-STAT signaling not only plays an important role in antiviral innate immunity, but also primes and shapes the adaptive immune response (Fleming, 2016; Villarino et al., 2015).
question: In IFN-activated JAK–STAT signaling, which step-by-step sequence of events best describes how STAT proteins become able to enter the nucleus and bind DNA regulatory elements (e.g., ISRE and GAS) to initiate interferon-stimulated gene transcription?
A: IFN receptor conformational change → STAT SH2 binding to phosphorylated receptor tyrosines → JAK transphosphorylation → STAT phosphorylation → STAT dimerization and nuclear translocation
B: IFN binding → STAT phosphorylation by receptor intrinsic kinase activity → STAT binding to receptor phosphotyrosines via SH2 → STAT monomer nuclear import → ISRE/GAS binding without cofactors
C: IFN receptor conformational change → receptor dimer/oligomer formation → JAK apposition and transphosphorylation → phosphorylation of receptor cytoplasmic tyrosines → STAT SH2 docking → STAT phosphorylation → STAT dissociation, dimerization, and nuclear translocation to bind ISRE/GAS
D: IFN binding → receptor tyrosine phosphorylation by STATs → JAK recruitment via STAT SH2 domains → STAT-JAK heterodimerization in cytosol → nuclear translocation and ISRE/GAS binding

question:
Contextual materials: Duck virus enteritis (DVE), also called duck plague, is one of the major contagious and fatal diseases of ducks, geese and swan. It is caused by duck enteritis virus (DEV)/Anatid herpesvirus-1 of the genus Mardivirus, family Herpesviridae, and subfamily Alpha-herpesvirinae. Of note, DVE has worldwide distribution, wherein migratory waterfowl plays a crucial role in its transmission within and between continents. Furthermore, horizontal and/or vertical transmission plays a significant role in disease spread through oral-fecal discharges. Either of sexes from varying age groups of ducks is vulnerable to DVE. The disease is characterized by sudden death, vascular damage and subsequent internal hemorrhage, lesions in lymphoid organs, digestive mucosal eruptions, severe diarrhea and degenerative lesions in parenchymatous organs. Huge economic losses are connected with acute nature of the disease, increased morbidity and mortality  $(5\% - 100\%)$ , condemnations of carcasses, decreased egg production and hatchability. Although clinical manifestations and histopathology can provide preliminary diagnosis, the confirmatory diagnosis involves virus isolation and detection using serological and molecular tests. For prophylaxis, both live-attenuated and killed vaccines are being used in broiler and breeder ducks above 2 weeks of age. Since DEV is capable of becoming latent as well as shed intermittently, recombinant subunit and DNA vaccines either alone or in combination (polyvalent) are being targeted for its benign prevention. question: A region is developing a control plan for anatid herpesvirus-1, where migratory waterfowl connect several continents. Which choice best combines (1) the major epidemiologic factor behind long-distance transmission, (2) the main shedding pathway that promotes widespread dissemination, and (3) a vaccination approach justified by the virus’s tendency for latency and intermittent shedding?
A: Domestic poultry trade as the sole intercontinental driver; vector-borne transmission through arthropods; preference for polyvalent recombinant vaccines mainly to reduce carcass condemnation rather than address shedding
B: Migratory waterfowl as intercontinental amplifiers; oral–fecal discharge enabling horizontal and/or vertical spread; shift toward recombinant subunit/DNA vaccines because latency with intermittent shedding complicates eradication
C: Climate-driven persistence in water as the main driver; transovarial transmission only; exclusive use of live-attenuated vaccines below 2 weeks of age to prevent establishment of latency
D: Migratory waterfowl as minor dead-end hosts; aerosol transmission as the dominant route; reliance on killed vaccines primarily because latency prevents live-attenuated vaccines from inducing immunity
Contextual materials: Duck virus enteritis (DVE), also called duck plague, is one of the major contagious and fatal diseases of ducks, geese and swan. It is caused by duck enteritis virus (DEV)/Anatid herpesvirus-1 of the genus Mardivirus, family Herpesviridae, and subfamily Alpha-herpesvirinae. Of note, DVE has worldwide distribution, wherein migratory waterfowl plays a crucial role in its transmission within and between continents. Furthermore, horizontal and/or vertical transmission plays a significant role in disease spread through oral-fecal discharges. Either of sexes from varying age groups of ducks is vulnerable to DVE. The disease is characterized by sudden death, vascular damage and subsequent internal hemorrhage, lesions in lymphoid organs, digestive mucosal eruptions, severe diarrhea and degenerative lesions in parenchymatous organs. Huge economic losses are connected with acute nature of the disease, increased morbidity and mortality  $(5\% - 100\%)$ , condemnations of carcasses, decreased egg production and hatchability. Although clinical manifestations and histopathology can provide preliminary diagnosis, the confirmatory diagnosis involves virus isolation and detection using serological and molecular tests. For prophylaxis, both live-attenuated and killed vaccines are being used in broiler and breeder ducks above 2 weeks of age. Since DEV is capable of becoming latent as well as shed intermittently, recombinant subunit and DNA vaccines either alone or in combination (polyvalent) are being targeted for its benign prevention. This review describes DEV, epidemiology, transmission, the disease (DVE), pathogenesis, and advances in diagnosis, vaccination and antiviral agents/therapies along with appropriate prevention and control strategies.

Contextual materials: USP18 (also known as UBP43) is a member of the ubiquitin-specific protease (UBP) family (Liu et al., 1999; Schwer et al., 2000). The UBP family is composed of deubiquitinating enzymes that regulate the balance of protein ubiquitination in combination with the action of ubiquitin-conjugating enzymes in a variety of cellular events (Chung and Baek, 1999; D'Andrea and Pellman, 1998; Guo et al., 2014; Wing, 2003). The family members differ in protein size and amino acid sequence; however, all share several consensus sequences surrounding the cysteine residues (Cys domain) and histidine residues (His domain) that are required for catalytic activity of the enzyme (Hochstrasser, 1996). USP18 was originally identified as a type I interferon-responsive gene that is rapidly upregulated by IFN-  $\beta$  treatment through the JAK/STAT kinase pathway (Kang et al., 2001). USP18 efficiently cleaves ISG15 conjugates, maintaining cellular homeostasis of ISG15-conjugated proteins (Malakhov et al., 2002). USP18 also negatively regulates type I IFN signaling independent of its ISG15 isopeptidase activity (Kim et al., 2006; Malakhova et al., 2006).
question: Which option best describes USP18’s two main functions, while correctly differentiating how it is induced upstream from the catalytic residues required for its enzymatic activity?
A: USP18 is constitutively expressed and primarily acts as an E2 ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme that promotes ISG15 attachment, thereby dampening type I IFN signaling through increased ISGylation
B: USP18 is induced by IFN-γ via the JAK/STAT pathway, cleaves ubiquitin but not ISG15 conjugates, and suppresses type I IFN signaling strictly through its deubiquitinating catalytic activity
C: USP18 is induced by IFN-β via the JAK/STAT pathway, requires conserved Cys/His domains for its deISGylating activity, and can attenuate type I IFN signaling even when its ISG15 isopeptidase function is not required
D: USP18 is induced by IFN-β via NF-κB signaling, depends on serine protease catalytic residues to remove ISG15 from substrates, and downregulates type I IFN signaling only by deISGylating JAK kinases
